revision.text:
{{update|date=May 2015}} [[File:Syracuse NY.jpg|thumb|350px|Downtown Syracuse, 2011]] '''Downtown Syracuse''' is the economic center of [[Syracuse, New York]], and [[Central New York]], employing over 30,000 people, and housing over 3,500. It is also one of the 26 officially recognized [[neighborhood]]s of Syracuse.{{Clear}} {| border="1" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" align="right" width="325px" style="margin:0 0 1em 1em" |+'''Downtown Syracuse''' |- | align="center" colspan=2 style="border-bottom:3px solid gray;" | ''Alternative Name: ''Cuse'' |- | align="center" bgcolor="white" colspan=2 | [[Image:Syracuse Downtown Location.gif|200px]]
Location in Syracuse |- |Annexed || - |- | [[Population]] (2017) || 3,500 |- | Median age || 31.5 |- | [[Median household income]] || $9,940 |- | [[Owner-occupier|Owner-occupied]] housing || 1.4% |- | [[ZIP code]]s || 13202, 13206 |} == History == [[Image:SyracuseSalinaHistoric.jpg|thumb|left|Downtown Syracuse during its golden years. This photo is of South Salina Street around 1915.]] Downtown Syracuse, as the rest of the city, grew as a result of the city's [[Salt industry in Syracuse, New York|salt industry]] and its location on the [[Erie Canal]]. For over a century, it was also the retail and entertainment center of [[Central New York]], with large department stores such as [[Chappell's]], The Addis Co., Flah's, E.W. Edwards, [[F.W. Woolworth Company|Woolworth]]'s, Grant's, Lincoln Stores, The Mohican, David's, Kresge's, Clark Music Co., Dey Brothers, and Sibley's. This attribute began to fade with development of large [[suburb]]an malls, with the final blow in 1992 when the combined Addis & Dey's department store became the last major store to leave downtown. ===South Salina Street=== South Salina Street between Erie Boulevard and West Onondaga Street was the main north-south artery of Downtown [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]] and was among the busiest streets in the city.{{cite web |url=http://www.yestercuse.com/salina.htm |title=Salina Street |accessdate=November 28, 2010 |first= |last= |publisher=Yestercuse, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718141213/http://www.yestercuse.com/salina.htm |archivedate=July 18, 2011 |df= }} The area has seen a great deal of revitalization in recent years with projects such as the conversion of the historic Syracuse Trust Building into luxury condos, a project engineered by local developer [[Peter Muserlian]]. More development projects are planned.http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2010/07/centro_receives_millions_from.html ===Cobblestone streets=== In 1835, the "nature of the soil and the flat surface of the ground" in the village rendered the construction of stone pavements necessary. An ordinance was passed authorizing the paving with [[cobblestone]] of Salina Street from Fayette to Church Streets and Genesee Street from the west line of [[Clinton Square]] to ''[[Hanover Square, Syracuse|Hanover Square]]''. Additionally, sections of Water, Warren and Franklin Streets were paved.{{cite news |title=Street Paving |newspaper=[[Syracuse Herald]] |first=|last=|location=[[Syracuse, New York]] January 16, 1881| accessdate=November 26, 2010}} The paving of these streets also made it necessary to pave the public squares, or the work would be "incomplete." A sum of $4,500 was raised with general tax. During the same year, sidewalks of brick were ordered to be constructed along all paved streets and squares where they had not already been laid including Salina Street from Washington Street to Onondaga Avenue. ===Armory Square=== {{Main|Armory Square}} ''Armory Square'' is a small neighborhood on the west side of Downtown [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]]. It began life as a busy commercial and industrial area just to the west of the central city. Named after the historic armory building that still inhabits the district's center, Armory Square is now home to luxury condos, restaurants, cafes, and high-end office space. ===Forman Park=== {{Main|Forman Park}} ''Forman Park'' was first established on June 16, 1839, and was known as ''Forman Square''. The main attraction is a bronze memorial of early civic leaders Joshua Forman and Lewis H. Redfield. The park is 1.3 acres and is located at East Genesee and Almond Streets.{{cite news |title=Forman Square |newspaper=[[Syracuse Herald]] |location=Syracuse, New York |first= |last=|date=February 6, 1881}} ===Clinton Square=== [[Image:Syracuse 1909 clinton-square.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Clinton Square looking west in Syracuse, New York in 1909 with Erie Canal in forefront - Bastable Block in rear and old County Courthouse to right]] {{Main|Clinton Square}} ''Clinton Square'' first came into existence in the early 19th century when roadways from north and south joined in downtown Syracuse. By the mid-19th century, the construction of [[Erie Canal]] further transformed the busy intersection into the center of commerce and trade in [[Central New York]].{{cite web|url=http://www.clintonsquare.com/ |title=Clinton Square |accessdate=November 25, 2010 |first=Steve |last=Johnson |publisher=ClintonSquare.com, 2010}} [[Image:Hanover-square 1900 veterans-park.jpg|left|thumb|180px|Veteran's Park in Syracuse, New York about 1900 - Later renamed Hanover Square]] ===Hanover Square=== {{Main|Hanover Square, Syracuse}} ''Hanover Square'' is actually a triangle at the intersection of Warren, Water, and East Genesee Streets. The name may also refer to the larger ''Hanover Square Historic District'', which includes seventeen historic buildings in the area that was the first commercial district in [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]].{{cite web|last=Connors|first=Dennis|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory/Nomination: Hanover Square Historic District|url=http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=6313 |date=December 1975 |accessdate=2009-01-13}} The public square was originally named ''Veteran's Park''. It was renamed to [[Hanover Square, Syracuse|Hanover Square]] after the ''Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument'' in [[Clinton Square]] was dedicated in 1910 and the function of commemorating [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse's]] war dead was shifted there. The larger [[Clinton Square]] had already developed as the city's center to the west, but following the completion of the [[Erie Canal]] in 1825, commercial and retail activity spread along Genesee Street to [[Hanover Square, Syracuse|Hanover Square]].{{cite web|url=http://syracusethenandnow.org/Dwntwn/HanoverSq/HanoverSquare.htm |title=Hanover Square |accessdate=December 5, 2010 |first= |last= |publisher=Syracuse Then and Now, 2010}} === Community profile === [[Image:Andrews-bros-markets 1902-0620.gif|right|thumb|300px|Advertisement for Andrew Brothers Markets in Syracuse, New York in June 1902]] Today, downtown Syracuse is an economic center, with many insurance companies, banks, and law firms having a large presence there. Since the late 1980s, downtown Syracuse has also increasingly become a [[nightlife (activity)|nightlife]] center, with many bars, clubs, restaurants, and pubs located in the ''[[Armory Square]]'' area. Most of Syracuse's cultural festivals, such as [[Oktoberfest celebrations|Oktoberfest]] and Festa Italiana, also take place downtown. The ''Downtown Committee of Syracuse'' has taken a great deal of effort to revitalize the area. Most sidewalks and streetlights have been restored since 1995, with maps and other information posted on many street corners. All of downtown is lively on weekdays, but on nights and weekends most activity centers around the ''[[Armory Square]]'', ''[[Hanover Square, Syracuse|Hanover Square]]'', and ''[[Clinton Square, Syracuse|Clinton Square]]'' areas. With the reopening of the historic ''[[Marriott Syracuse Downtown]]'' in 2016, there are currently three hotels downtown. ===National Register of Historic Places=== The following are listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] and located in Downtown Syracuse: [[Amos Block]], [[Armory Square Historic District]], [[Central New York Telephone and Telegraph Building]], [[Central Technical High School]], [[Gere Bank Building]], [[Gridley Building]], [[Hanover Square (Syracuse)|Hanover Square Historic District]], [[Hotel Syracuse]], [[Landmark Theatre (Syracuse, New York)|Loew's State Theater]], [[Montgomery Street-Columbus Circle Historic District]], [[New York Central Railroad Passenger and Freight Station]], [[Niagara Hudson Building]], [[Onondaga County Savings Bank Building]], [[Onondaga County War Memorial]], [[Plymouth Congregational Church (Syracuse, New York)|Plymouth Congregational Church]], [[Saint Paul's Episcopal Cathedral (Syracuse, New York)|St. Paul's Cathedral and Parish House]], [[C.W. Snow and Company Warehouse]], [[South Salina Street Downtown Historic District]], [[Syracuse City Hall]], [[Syracuse Savings Bank]], [[Third National Bank (Syracuse, New York)|Third National Bank]], [[Weighlock Building]], [[White Memorial Building (Syracuse, New York)|White Memorial Building]], and [[Hamilton White House]].{{NRISref|version=2010a}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/listings/20100625.htm |title=Announcements and actions on properties for the National Register of Historic Places for June 25, 2010 |date=June 25, 2010 |accessdate=2010-09-01 |work=Weekly Listings |publisher=[[National Park Service]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cr.nps.gov/nr/listings/20120210.htm|title=National Register of Historic Places Listings|date=2012-02-10|work=Weekly List of Actions Taken on Properties: 1/30/12 through 2/03/12 |publisher=National Park Service}} == Recent years == In December 2005, [[Syracuse University]] announced it had purchased eleven buildings downtown, and leased another. Hundreds of faculty, staff, and students began using the buildings in the spring of 2006. Former [[Syracuse University]] chancellor [[Nancy Cantor]]'s motto for the venture was "Exploring the Soul of Syracuse." At the same time, the university and the city were working on a project called the "Connective Corridor," a special path from the university area to [[Armory Square]]. The main building of [[Syracuse University]] downtown is [[The Warehouse (Syracuse)|The Warehouse]]. ==See also== {{Portal|Syracuse, New York}} *[[List of tallest buildings in Syracuse, New York]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://downtownsyracuse.com Downtown Committee of Syracuse] {{Syracuse Neighborhoods}} {{Syracuse, New York}} {{coord missing|New York (state)}} [[Category:Neighborhoods in Syracuse, New York]] [[Category:Central business districts in the United States|Syracuse]]

'''Edward Manuel Fram''' (1905–1955) was a Christian Iraqi businessman, merchant and philanthropist.
[[File:Edward M Fram.jpg|thumb|right|Edward Fram]]
==Business activities==
===Insurance=== Living and working in [[Basra]] in what was then the [[Kingdom of Iraq]], Edward Fram was a key figure in the country's [[Insurance in Iraq|modern insurance industry]], as the owner of one of Iraq's first [[insurance]] agencies operating under the Insurance Companies Act No. 74 (1 April 1936). This was the first Iraqi law passed to specifically regulate the industry.<ref name="almosul1">{{cite web|url=http://www.almosul.com/Heritage/History/IraqHistory/Begining_of_Insurance_Iraq.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Beginnings of Insurance and Regulation of Insurance Activity in Iraq - An Overview |author=Misbah Kamal |website=Almosul.com |accessdate=2015-12-28}}</ref> Prior to this, only 3 insurance companies were known to be operating in Iraq, under the Ottoman Commercial Law of 9 August 1904,<ref name="almosul1"/><ref>Hanna Batatu, The Old Social Classes and New Revolutionary Movements of Iraq, (London, al-Saqi Books, 2000)</ref> one of which was the General Accident Fire and Life Assurance Corporation (now Aviva Insurance Ltd.) from 1928.<ref name="aviva">{{cite web|url=http://heritage.aviva.com/our-history/companies/a/aviva-insurance-ltd/|publisher=heritage.aviva.com|title=Aviva Insurance Ltd - Heritage - Aviva plc|accessdate=2017-01-14}}</ref> By the time of the nationalisation of the industry in 1964, there were still just 15 branches and agencies of regional (Arab) and foreign insurance companies across Iraq, including Egypt's Al-Chark Insurance Company.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iraqshistory.blogspot.co.uk/2008/08/insurance-in-iraq-in-arabic-english.html |title=History of IRAQ: Insurance in IRAQ - in Arabic & English |website=Iraqshistory.blogspot.co.uk |date=2008-08-29 |accessdate=2015-12-28}}</ref> Al-Chark (part of Misr Insurance since 2007<ref>{{cite web|url=http://misrholding.co/Data/HTMLEditor/Doc/Misr%20Asset%20Management%20Company%20profile.pdf |format=PDF |title=Misr Holding : Company Profile |website=Misrholding.co |accessdate=2015-12-21}}</ref>) was the first to set up an agency in [[Emirate of Transjordan|Transjordan]] towards the end of the 1940s and was one of the first in Iraq, where Edward Fram acted as their agent from as early as 1936.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dNK9UZI7oscC&printsec=frontcover&dq=inauthor:%22Peter+Borscheid%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiGvr_MuOzJAhVFvBQKHVUhBJgQ6AEIGzAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=World Insurance|website=Books.google.co.uk|editor=Peter Borscheid|accessdate=2015-12-21}}</ref><ref name="misbahkamal">{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/3778468/Insurance_Agencies_in_Iraq_1936|title=Insurance Agencies in Iraq 1936|author=Misbah Kamal|website=Academia.edu|accessdate=2015-12-21}}</ref> Fram also represented France's oldest insurer L’Union de Paris (later UAP, now part of AXA) and other insurance companies, along with [[Shafiq Ades]], [[Andrew Weir, 1st Baron Inverforth]] and other notable businessmen.<ref name="misbahkamal"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://02e37fc.netsolhost.com/site/Commercial%20Directory%20of%20Iraq.pdf |format=PDF |title=Commercial Directory of Iraq |website=02e37c.netsolhost.com |accessdate=2015-12-21}}</ref>[[File:L'union de Paris insurance company, Baghdad Branch.jpg|thumb|right|Agents and representatives of L'Union de Paris, Baghdad Branch. Edward Fram (top right), Clement Shammas (top left). In 1966, Shammas was appointed by Iraq’s then Prime Minister [[Abdul Rahman al-Bazzaz]] as the head of the Iraqi Insurance Organisation (abolished in 1988). Taken by A.Abbosh & Co., photographer who held the Royal Warrant to H.M. the King of Iraq; date unknown.]]
===Bonds and securities=== Fram was one of the first and main players in Basra's nascent [[Bond (finance)|bonds]] and securities markets from the mid-1930s.<ref name="auto">The Iraq Directory 1936, p. 139, p. 150, p. 152 and p. 194 (published by Dangoor Printing House under the supervision of the Iraqi Ministry of the Interior)</ref> His name is the only one listed in the Basra bonds section within Iraq's sole pre-Baathist business directory, published by the Interior Ministry in 1936.<ref name="auto"/>
===Other=== Fram was a major goods importer, exporter, makers' representative and also acted as the exclusive agent in Iraq for [[Selfridges]], amongst other western companies. During the Second World War, he provided housing for British troops as part of the development of Basra as a "large-scale base"<ref name="google">{{cite book|title=The Grand Alliance|author=Churchill, W.|date=1986|publisher=Houghton Mifflin|isbn=9780395410578|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zVdux2KfenoC&pg=PA404|page=404|accessdate=2017-01-14}}</ref><ref>http://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/UN/UK/LondonGazette/37685.pdf</ref> and traded scrap metal left by the British military after the war, as did other well-known merchants such as Naji Al-Khedhairi.<ref name="iraqijews">{{cite web|url=http://www.iraqijews.org/commlead.html|publisher=iraqijews.org|title=Community Leaders|accessdate=2017-01-14}}</ref> Fram also ran the Basra office of [[Iraq Tours]], the country's first travel agency, which had Iraqi Prime Minister [[Tawfiq al-Suwaydi]] as chairman, and which played a key role in [[Operation Ezra and Nehemiah]] alongside the Near East Transport Company and the Israeli national airline El Al.<ref name="dailycaller">{{cite web|url=http://dailycaller.com/2016/06/03/when-iraq-expelled-its-jews-to-israel-the-inside-story/|publisher=dailycaller.com|title=When Iraq Expelled Its Jews To Israel: The Inside Story | The Daily Caller|accessdate=2017-01-14}}</ref><ref name="google2">{{cite book|title=The Jewish Exodus from Iraq, 1948-1951|author=Gat, M.|date=2013|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=9781135246549|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B_r3_-9ZU1YC&pg=PA97|page=97|accessdate=2017-01-14}}</ref><ref name="google3">{{cite book|title=The Making of Modern Israel: 1948-1967|author=Stein, L.|date=2013|publisher=Wiley|isbn=9780745636238|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nWkYAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT23|accessdate=2017-01-14}}</ref>
==Death== Edward Fram died aged 50 in a car accident, a short distance from his hometown of Basra, on his return from a visit to the [[Hanna-Sheikh]] family's [[Abu Al-Khaseeb]] retreat. A member of the Al-Sa'adoon family with whom he was travelling also died in the crash, along with the chauffeur.
==Family and legacy== Edward Fram was survived by seven children (five daughters, two sons) and his wife, Selima (1920–1961). His youngest daughter, Thelma Edward Marougy (née Fram), is a fluid specialist at [[Eaton Corporation]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2FBF01393562 |title=The X-ray crystal structure of two osmium(VI) catecholato complexes, Os(O2C6H4)3 and Os[O2C6H2(Bu-t)2]3 |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29 |doi=10.1007/BF01393562 |volume=3 |pages=255–256 |journal=Transition Metal Chemistry|year=1978 |last1=Hursthouse |first1=Michael B. |last2=Fram |first2=Thelma |last3=New |first3=Lucy |last4=Griffith |first4=William P. |last5=Nielson |first5=Alastair J. }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfpa.com/tech_papers/2000/i00-9_12.pdf |format=PDF |title=Technical Paper Series : Fluid Viscosity Selection Criteria for Hydraulic Pumps and Motors |author=Paul W. Michael |website=Nfpa.com |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kerns |first=Jeff |url=http://machinedesign.com/hydraulics/making-move-eco-friendly-hydraulic-fluids |title=Making the Move to Eco-friendly Hydraulic Fluids | Hydraulics content from |publisher=Machine Design |date=2013-08-07 |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eaton.com/ecm/groups/public/@pub/@eaton/@hyd/documents/content/ct_172164.pdf |format=PDF |title=Fluid Power Journal |website=Eaton.com |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref> Edward Fram is the grandfather of American technology executive and namesake, [[Edward Y Abbo]] - formerly Senior Vice President at [[Oracle Corporation]] and currently President and Chief Technical Officer at C3 IoT,<ref name="c3iot">{{cite web|url=http://c3iot.com/about/leadership/#executive-team|publisher=c3iot.com|title=Leadership - C3 IoT|accessdate=2017-01-14}}</ref> a data analytics company founded in 2009 by [[Thomas Siebel|Tom Siebel]]. He is also the grandfather of Michael Y Abbo, an emergency physician and assistant clinical professor at the [[University of California San Francisco]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://esem2014.com/dr-michael-abbo/ |title=Dr.Michael Abbo |website=ESEM2014.com |date=2015-01-27 |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref> Ayad Sarraf, former manager of [[Fulham Deaf FC]] and now club secretary,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hearingtimes.co.uk/Video/1087/Fulham%20Deaf%20FC%20win%20cup%20final |title=Fulham Deaf FC win cup final |website=Hearingtimes.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2013/may/07/fulham-deaf-fc |title=Fulham Deaf FC Win Cup | Fulham Football Club |website=Fulhamfc.com |date=2013-05-07 |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref> Luisa Toffolatti, an Italian oncologist and researcher based in Treviso <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Luisa_Toffolatti/citations |title=Luisa Toffolatti - Citations |website=Researchgate.net |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref> and Sally Fram, PhD - a British cancer expert and regulatory affairs executive at [[AstraZeneca]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zoominfo.com/p/Sally-Fram/1965821195 |title=Sally Fram | AstraZeneca PLC |website=ZoomInfo.com |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |date=2011 |doi=10.1007/978-1-61779-207-6_3 |chapter=HGF-Induced DU145 Cell Scatter Assay |title=Cell Migration |volume=769 |pages=31 |series=Methods in Molecular Biology |last1=Fram |first1=Sally T. |last2=Wells |first2=Claire M. |last3=Jones |first3=Gareth E. |editor-first=Claire M. |editor-last=Wells |editor-first2=Maddy |editor-last2=Parsons |isbn=978-1-61779-206-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00018-013-1528-5#page-1 |title=A PAK6–IQGAP1 complex promotes disassembly of cell–cell adhesions |date=2013-12-19 |accessdate=2015-12-29 |doi=10.1007/s00018-013-1528-5 |volume=71 |issue=14 |pages=2759–2773 |journal=Cellular and Molecular Life Sciences|last1=Fram |first1=Sally |last2=King |first2=Helen |last3=Sacks |first3=David B. |last4=Wells |first4=Claire M. |pmid=24352566 |pmc=4059965}}</ref> Edward Fram is the great-grandfather of Rafi Allos, an intellectual property specialist and associate at [[Allen and Overy]].<ref>http://www.allenovery.com/people/en-gb/Pages/Rafi-Allos.aspx</ref>

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=August 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=July 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Ephraim Bagenda | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Rwanda]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = | occupation = [[Aerospace engineering|Aeronautical Engineer]] & [[Business Executive]] | years_active = | nationality = Rwandan | citizenship = Rwandan | residence = [[Entebbe]], [[Uganda]] | known_for = Business, Management | networth = | home_town = | title = [[Managing Director]]
[[Uganda Airlines]] | spouse = }} '''Ephraim Kalyebara Bagenda''' is a Rwandan [[aeronautical engineer]] and [[business executive]], who serves as the [[managing director]] and [[chief executive officer]] of [[Uganda Airlines]], the revived national airline of [[Uganda]].{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uganda-aviation/airbus-inks-deal-to-sell-passenger-planes-to-uganda-idUSKBN1K82L1 |title=Airbus inks deal to sell passenger planes to Uganda |access-date=19 July 2018 |date=18 July 2018 | publisher=[[Reuters.com]] |first=Elias |last=Biryabarema}} He assumed that position in 2018, having served as the Director of Maintenance and Engineering at [[Rwandair]], until late 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.hoovers.com/company-information/cs/company-profile.rwandair.060f58eea7275374.html | title=D&B Hovers: Get in Touch with 3 Contacts at Rwandair: Ephraim K. Bagenda, Director of Maintenance & Engineering | publisher=[[D&B Hoovers]] |author=D&B Hoovers |location=Austin, Texas |date=2017 |access-date=19 July 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://256businessnews.com/gad-gasatura-tapped-for-uganda-airlines-chief-as-carrier-pays-for-aircraft/ | title=Gad Gasatura tapped for Uganda Airlines chief as carrier pays for aircraft |access-date=19 July 2018 |date=2 May 2018 | publisher=256Businessnews.com |author=256Businessnews Staff | location=Kampala}} ==Education and training== Bagenda is a professional aircraft engineer.{{cite web|access-date=19 July 2018 |date=19 July 2018 |url=https://airportguide.com/airmen/A3810572/EPHRAIM-KALYEBARA-BAGENDA |title=Airman Information for Ephraim Kalyebara Bagenda | publisher=© 1998-2018 AirportGuide.com |author=AirportGuide.com}} ==Career== In 2017, he served as the Director of maintenance and engineering at Rwandair, serving there for nearly six years.{{cite web|date=2017 | url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/ephraim-bagenda-a6104b36/ | title=Ephraim Bagenda: Technical Director at Rwandair | access-date=19 July 2018 |publisher=[[LinkedIn]] |first=Ephraim |last=Bagenda}} In 2018, he was appointed as the managing director and CEO of the revived national carrier, Uganda Airlines,{{cite web| url=https://chimpreports.com/uganda-airlines-signs-shs-700bn-firm-order-for-4-bombardier-crj900-aircraft/ |title=Uganda Airlines Signs Shs700 Billon Firm Order for 4 Bombardier CRJ900 Aircraft |access-date=19 July 2018 |date=18 July 2018 |first=Sam |last=Waswa |publisher=Chimp Reports Uganda |location=Kampala}} although a different member of the team had been considered for the job. In July 2018, while at the [[Farnborough Airshow]], he signed two [[memorandum|memoranda of understanding]], with aircraft manufacturers for six jets to re-open the airline.{{cite web|access-date=19 July 2018 |newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] |date=18 July 2018 |author=Monitor Reporter |location=Kampala |url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Uganda-Airlines-signs-deal-buy-Bombardier-jets/688334-4670300-6xxwjiz/index.html | title=Uganda Airlines Signs Deal to Buy 4 Bombardier Jets, Two Airbuses}} The first agreement was with [[Bombardier Inc.|Bombardier Commercial Aircraft]] of Canada for a firm purchase order of four [[CRJ900|CRJ900-ER]] aircraft at an estimated total price of US$190 million. The four jets will feature the Bombardier Atmosphère Cabin; Uganda Airlines being the first carrier to operate that type of aircraft on the African continent.{{cite web|access-date=19 July 2018 |date=18 July 2018 |url=https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/uganda-national-airlines-company-limited-signs-firm-order-for-four-bombardier-crj900-aircraft-1027378640 |title=Uganda National Airlines Company Limited Signs Firm Order for Four Bombardier CRJ900 Aircraft |publisher=[[Business Insider]] |author=Press Release via GlobeNewswire |location=New York City}} The second agreement was with the European aerospace conglomerate, [[Airbus|Airbus SA]] for a firm purchase of two [[Airbus A330neo|A330-800neo]] aircraft, featuring the improved and fuel-efficient [[Rolls-Royce Trent 7000]].{{cite web|url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/business/Airbus-inks-deal-to-sell-passenger-planes-to-Uganda/2560-4670742-963w3e/index.html |title=Airbus Inks Deal to Sell Passenger Planes to Uganda |access-date=19 July 2018 |date=19 July 2018 | newspaper=[[The EastAfrican]] |last=Reuters | first=and Charles Mpagi |location=Nairobi}} The long-haul jets will feature three-class cabins with maximum capacity of 261 passengers, comprising 20seats in Business Class, 28 in Premium Economy and 213 in Economy Class. ==See also== * [[Transport in Uganda]] * [[List of airports in Uganda]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.ugandaairlines.com/ Website of Revived Uganda Airlines] * [https://Careers.ugandaairlines.com/ Careers Website Of Uganda Airlines] * [https://aviationbusinessjournal.aero/2018/07/19/uganda-airlines-orders-two-a330neo/ Uganda Airlines Orders Two A330neo] {{DEFAULTSORT:Bagenda, Ephraim}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Rwandan businesspeople]] [[Category:Rwandan business executives]] [[Category:Chief executive officers]]

page.title: Federal Reserve Bank of New York

revision.text:
{{coord|40|42|30|N|74|0|31|W|region:US-NY_type:landmark|display=title}} [[File:2015 Federal Reserve Bank of New York from west.jpg|thumb|267px|[[Federal Reserve Bank of New York Building]]]] The '''Federal Reserve Bank of New York''' is one of the 12 [[Federal Reserve Bank]]s of the [[United States]]. It is located at [[33 Liberty Street]], [[New York City|New York]], [[New York State|NY]]. It is responsible for the Second District of the [[Federal Reserve System]], which encompasses [[New York (state)|New York State]], the 12 northern counties of [[New Jersey]], [[Fairfield County, Connecticut|Fairfield County]] in [[Connecticut]], [[Puerto Rico]], and the [[U.S. Virgin Islands]]. Working within the Federal Reserve System, the New York Federal Reserve Bank implements monetary policy, supervises and regulates financial institutions{{cite web| url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/story/29127316/the_great_american_bubble_machine/6| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100406021652/http://www.rollingstone.com/politics/story/29127316/the_great_american_bubble_machine/6| title=The Great American Bubble Machine| work=Rolling Stone| page=6| archivedate=April 6, 2010| accessdate=Sep 9, 2012| author=[[Matt Taibbi]]| date=July 13, 2009}} and helps maintain the nation's payment systems.[http://www.newyorkfed.org/aboutthefed/index.html/ "About the Fed."] New York Federal Reserve Web page. Footnote upgraded/confirmed 2010-03-30. Among the other regional banks, New York Federal Reserve Bank and its president are considered first among equals.http://www.slate.com/id/2217811/ Its current president is [[John C. Williams (economist)|John C. Williams]]. It is by far the largest (by assets), most active (by volume) and most influential of the 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks. ==Responsibilities== The New York Fed publishes a [http://www.newyorkfed.org/research/capital_markets/ycfaq.html monthly recession probability prediction] derived from the [[yield curve]] and based on the work by Dr. Arturo Estrella & Dr. Tobias Adrian. Their models show that, when the difference between short-term interest rates (using three-month [[T-bills]]) and long-term interest rates (using ten-year Treasury bonds) at the end of a Federal Reserve tightening cycle is negative or less than 93 basis points positive, a rise in unemployment usually occurs.Arturo Estrella & Tobias Adrian, ''[http://www.newyorkfed.org/research/staff_reports/sr397.pdf FRB of New York Staff Report No. 397]'', 2009 ==Largest regional Federal Reserve Bank== [[File:New York Fed map.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Map of the Second District]] [[Image:Federal Reserve Districts Map.svg|400px|thumb|Map of Federal Reserve districts]] Since the founding of the Federal Reserve banking system, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in [[Manhattan]]'s Financial District has been the place where monetary policy in the United States is implemented, although policy is decided in Washington, D.C. by the [[Federal Reserve Board of Governors]]. The New York Fed is the largest in terms of assets of the twelve regional banks. Operating in the financial capital of the U.S., the New York Fed is responsible for conducting [[open market operations]], the buying and selling of outstanding [[Treasury security|U.S. Treasury securities]]. The '''Trading Desk''' is the office at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York that manages the FOMC Directive to sell or buy bonds.http://www.ny.frb.org/aboutthefed/fedpoint/fed32.html Note that the responsibility for ''issuing'' new U.S. Treasury securities lies with the [[Bureau of the Public Debt]]. In 2003, [[Fedwire]], the Federal Reserve's system for transferring balances between it and other banks, transferred $1.8 trillion a day in funds, of which about $1.1 trillion originated in the Second District. It transferred an additional $1.3 trillion a day in securities, of which $1.2 trillion originated in the Second District. The New York Fed is also responsible for carrying out [[exchange rate]] policy by buying and selling dollars at the discretion of the United States Treasury Department. The New York Federal Reserve is the only regional bank with a permanent vote on the [[Federal Open Market Committee]] and its president is traditionally selected as the Committee's vice chairman. ==Move to 33 Liberty Street== {{further|33 Liberty Street}} [[File:Goldvault nyc.jpg|thumb|Vast quantities of gold were shipped to the U.S. during World War I and stored in the U.S. Federal Reserve Banks. Today gold is still stored at the bank.]] A public [[architectural design competition|competition for the design of the building]] was held and the architectural firm of [[York and Sawyer]] submitted the winning design. The bank moved to its current location in 1924.[http://www.newyorkfed.org/aboutthefed/history_article.html "History"]. New York Federal Reserve Web page. Retrieved 2010-03-30. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York maintains a vault that lies {{convert|80|ft}} below street level and {{convert|50|ft}} below sea level,{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorkfed.org/education/addpub/goldvault.pdf|title=The Key to the Gold Vault|publisher=The Federal Reserve Bank of New York|accessdate=18 September 2010}} resting on Manhattan bedrock. By 1927, the vault contained 10% of the world's [[official gold reserves]]. Currently, it is reputedly the largest [[gold]] repository in the world (though this cannot be confirmed as [[Switzerland|Swiss]] banks do not report their gold stocks) and holds approximately {{convert|7,000|t|ST|lk=on}} of gold bullion ($415 billion as of October 2011), more than [[United States Bullion Depository|Fort Knox]]. Nearly 98% of the gold at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York is owned by the central banks of foreign nations.''Mightiest Bank.'' Aired on Monday, 14 November 2011, 7:00pm - 8:00pm EST on [[Planet Green]]. 51 minutes. (See also [http://ffh.films.com/id/1666?TrackingID=BVL ''Inside the World’s Mightiest Bank: The Federal Reserve.''] Tug Yourgrau and Pip Gilmour. Princeton, NJ: Films for the Humanities & Sciences. 2000. Originally produced for the Discovery Channel by Powderhouse Productions. Retrieved 14 November 2011) The rest is owned by the United States and international organizations such as the [[IMF]]. The Federal Reserve Bank does not own the gold but serves as guardian of the precious metal, which it stores at no charge to the owners, but charging a $1.75 fee (in 2008) per bar to move the gold. Moving the bars requires special footwear for the staff, to protect their feet in case they drop one of the gold bars weighing {{convert|28|lb|kg|lk=on}}. The vault is open to tourists.http://abcnews.go.com/Business/story?id=5835433&page=1 ===Terrorism attempt=== On October 17, 2012, Quazi Mohammad Rezwanul Ahsan Nafis, 21, was arrested while attempting to detonate what he believed to be an 800-pound bomb. A joint [[FBI]]/[[NYPD]] operation flagged the suspect on the Internet and set up the sting with fake explosives. In 2013, Nafis pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 30 years in federal prison.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/10/nyregion/30-year-sentence-for-man-who-tried-to-bomb-federal-reserve.html?gwh=96F34C7C6DB3A945A88A8E34CC2FC9FB | work=The New York Times | first=Mosi | last=Secret | title=30-Year Prison Sentence in Plot to Bomb U.S. Bank | date=August 9, 2013}} ==Branches== The [[Federal Reserve Bank of New York Buffalo Branch]] used to be the only branch of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, but it was closed on October 31, 2008. ==History== ===Benjamin Strong, 1914-1928=== The New York Fed opened for business on November 16, 1914, under the leadership of [[Benjamin Strong Jr.]], who had previously been president of the Bankers Trust Company. He led the Bank until his death in 1928. Strong became the executive officer (then called the "governor"—today, the term would be "president"). As the leader of the Federal Reserve's largest and most powerful district bank, Strong became a dominant force in U.S. monetary and banking affairs. One biographer has termed him the "de facto leader of the entire Federal Reserve System."Lester Vernon Chandler, ''Benjamin Strong: Central Banker'' (1958) This was not only because of Strong's abilities, but also because the central board's powers were ambiguous and, for the most part, limited to supervisory and regulatory functions under the 1913 [[Federal Reserve Act]] because many Americans were antagonistic to centralized control. When the United States entered [[World War I]], Strong was a major force behind the campaigns to fund the war effort via bonds owned primarily by U.S. citizens. This enabled the United States to avoid many of the post-war financial problems of the European belligerents. Strong gradually recognized the importance of [[open market operation]], or purchases and sales of government [[Security (finance)|securities]], as a means of managing the quantity of money in the U.S. economy and thus affecting interest rates. This was particularly important at the time because gold had flooded into the United States during and after World War I. Thus, its gold-backed currency was well-protected, but prices had been pushed up substantially by the currency expansion due to the [[gold standard]]-imposed expansion of currency. In 1922, Strong unofficially scrapped the gold standard and instead began aggressively pursuing open market operations as a means of stabilizing domestic prices and thus internal economic stability. Thus, he began the Federal Reserve's practice of buying and selling government securities as monetary policy. [[John Maynard Keynes]], a prominent British economist who had previously not questioned the gold standard, used Strong's activities as an example of how a central bank could manage a nation's economy without the gold standard in his book "A Tract on Monetary Reform" (1923). To quote one authority:
It was Strong more than anyone else who invented the modern central banker. When we watch... [central bankers of today] describe how they are seeking to strike the right balance between economic growth and price stability, it is the ghost of Benjamin Strong who hovers above him. It all sounds quite prosaically obvious now, but in 1922 it was a radical departure from more than two hundred years of central banking history.Liaquat Ahamed, ''Lords of Finance: The Bankers Who Broke the World'' (2009), p. 171
Strong's policy of maintaining price levels during the 1920s through open market operation and his willingness to maintain the [[liquidity]] of banks during panics have been praised by [[monetarist]]s and harshly criticized by [[Austrian School|Austrian economists]]Rothbard, Murray, ''America's Great Depression'' (2000), page xxxiii With the European economic turmoil of the 1920s, Strong's influence became worldwide. He was a strong supporter of European efforts to return to the gold standard and economic stability. Strong's new monetary policies not only stabilized U.S. prices, they encouraged both U.S. and world trade by helping to stabilize European currencies and finances. However, with virtually no inflation, interest rates were low and the U.S. economy and corporate profits surged, fueling the stock market increases of the late 1920s. This worried him, but he also felt he had no choice because the low interest rates were helping Europeans (particularly Great Britain) in their effort to return to the gold standard. Economic historian [[Charles P. Kindleberger]] states that Strong was one of the few U.S. policymakers interested in the troubled financial affairs of Europe in the 1920s, and that had he not died in 1928, just a year before the [[Great Depression]], he might have been able to maintain stability in the international financial system;Kindleberger, Charles, ''[[The World in Depression, 1929-1939]],''(1986) After Strong died in 1928, the New York Bank lost its energetic leadership. In the 1930s some of its power was transferred to the Federal Reserve System headquarters in Washington. ==Criticisms== In 2009, the New York Federal Reserve Bank commissioned a probe into its own practices. David Beim, finance professor at Columbia Business School submitted a report in 2009, released by the [[Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission]] in 2011, saying "that a number of people he interviewed at the reserve bank believe that supervisors paid excessive deference to banks and, as a result, they were less aggressive in finding issues or in following up on them in a forceful way." {{cite news|author1=Matthew Boesler and Kathleen Hunter|title=Warren Calls for Hearings on New York Fed Allegations|work=Bloomberg News|date=27 September 2014|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-09-26/new-york-fed-denies-allegations-of-bank-supervision-lapse.html|accessdate=9 October 2014}} Following [[Stephen Friedman (PFIAB)|Stephen Friedman]]'s resignation on 7 May 2009, Denis Hughes, formerly Deputy Chair, was designated as Interim Chair. The current Chair (for 2013) is Emily Rafferty, President of the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]. In 2012, [[Carmen Segarra]], then New York Fed bank examiner, told her superiors that [[Goldman Sachs]] had no policy governing conflicts of interest. She was "fired in May 2012 after refusing to change her findings on the conflict-of-interest policy and sued the New York Fed October 2013". In April 2014 the U.S. District court in Manhattan dismissed the case, "ruling that Segarra failed to make a legally sufficient claim under the [[whistle-blower]] protections of the [[Federal Deposit Insurance Act]]". In September 2014, Segarra´s secretly recorded conversations were aired by ''[[This American Life]]'' and the New York Fed was accused of political corruption by being a "captured agency", ''i.e.'', subject to [[regulatory capture]], of the banks which it supervises.{{cite news|title=The Secret Recordings of Carmen Segarra|work=[[This American Life]]|date=26 September 2014|url=http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/536/the-secret-recordings-of-carmen-segarra}}{{cite news|title=Inside the New York Fed: Secret Recordings and a Culture Clash|first=Jake|last=Bernstein|date=26 September 2014|work=ProPublica.org|publisher=[[ProPublica]]|url=https://www.propublica.org/article/carmen-segarras-secret-recordings-from-inside-new-york-fed}} ==Board of Directors== The following people serve on the board of directors {{As of|2017|06|lc=yes}}.{{cite web|url=https://www.federalreserve.gov/aboutthefed/federal-reserve-system-new-york.htm |title=Federal Reserve Bank of New York - Directors |date=June 2017 |publisher=Federal Reserve}} Terms expire on December 31 of their final year on the board. {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Class A ! Name ! Title ! Term Expires |- ![[Paul P. Mello]] |President and Chief Executive Officer
[[Solvay Bank]]
[[Solvay, New York]] |2017 |- ![[James P. Gorman]] |Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
[[Morgan Stanley]]
[[New York, New York]] |2018 |- ! [[Gerald Lipkin]] | Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
[[Valley National Bank]]
[[Wayne, New Jersey]] |2019 |} {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Class B ! Name ! Title ! Term Expires |- ![[Terry J. Lundgren]] |Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
[[Macy's|Macy's, Inc.]]
New York, New York |2017 |- ![[Glenn Hutchins|Glenn H. Hutchins]] |Co-Founder
[[Silver Lake Partners|Silver Lake]]
New York, New York |2018 |- ![[David M. Cote]] |Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
[[Honeywell International Inc.]]
[[Morris Plains, New Jersey]] |2019 |} {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Class C ! Name ! Title ! Term Expires |- ![[Emily K. Rafferty]] |President Emerita
[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]
New York, New York |2017 |- ![[Sara Horowitz]] (Chair) |Founder and Executive Director
[[Freelancers Union]]
[[Brooklyn, New York]] |2018 |- ![[Denise Scott]] (Deputy Chair) |Executive Vice President
[[Local Initiatives Support Corporation]]
New York, New York |2019 |} ==Presidents== {{Main|List of Presidents of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York}} image: Benjamin_Strong_Jr.jpg | 1. [[Benjamin Strong, Jr.|Strong (1914–1928)]] image: George_L_Harrison.png | 2. [[George L. Harrison|Harrison (1928–1940)]] image: Paulvolcker.jpg | 5. [[Paul Volcker|Volcker (1975–1979)]] image: E_Gerald_Corrigan.gif | 7. [[E. Gerald Corrigan|Corrigan (1985–1993)]] image: Timothy_Geithner_official_portrait.jpg | 9. [[Timothy Geithner|Geithner (2003–2009)]] image: William_C._Dudley.jpg | 10. [[William C. Dudley|Dudley (2009–2018)]] image: John C. Williams (cropped).jpg | 11. [[John C. Williams (economist)|Williams (2018– )]] * 4. [[Alfred Hayes (banker)|Hayes (1956–1975)]] * 6. [[Anthony Morton Solomon|Solomon (1980–1985)]] * 8. [[William Joseph McDonough|McDonough (1993–2003)]] ==In popular culture== In the first ''[[The Godfather|Godfather]]'' movie, the "meeting of the Dons" scene uses the Federal Reserve building exterior, even though the interior of another New York building (the Penn Central railway boardroom) was also used for filming. In the 1974 film ''[[The Taking of Pelham One Two Three (1974 film)|The Taking of Pelham One Two Three]]'' hijackers take over a subway train car and demand $1 million for release of the car and 19 passengers, and the city must deliver it to the train car within one hour or the hijackers will start executing passengers at the rate of one per minute until it's delivered. The money for the ransom, to be provided in bundles of used $50 and $100 bills, is frantically assembled by workers at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York while a police cruiser waits at the front entrance for it to be assembled for delivery. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York plays a prominent role in the 1995 film ''[[Die Hard with a Vengeance]]'', starring [[Bruce Willis]] and [[Jeremy Irons]]. The Federal Reserve Bank is the setting for a major heist of the gold by Jeremy Irons' character, Simon Gruber. The vault is penetrated under the pretense of construction work and the gold bullion transported via dump trucks to a location outside the city. ==See also== * [[Economy of New York City]] * [[Federal Reserve Act]] * [[Federal Reserve System]] * [[Federal Reserve Districts]] * [[Federal Reserve Branches]] * [[Federal Reserve Bank of New York Buffalo Branch]] * [[Official gold reserves]] * [[Structure of the Federal Reserve System]] * [[East Rutherford Operations Center]] (regional office for cash handling and processing of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York) ==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist}} '''Further reading''' * Alessi, Lucia, et al. "Central bank macroeconomic forecasting during the global financial crisis: the European Central Bank and Federal Reserve Bank of New York experiences." ''Journal of Business & Economic Statistics'' (2014) 32#4 pp: 483-500. * Chandler, Lester Vernon. ''Benjamin Strong: Central Banker'' (Brookings Institution, 1958) * Clark, Lawrence Edmund. ''Central Banking Under the Federal Reserve System: With Special Consideration of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York'' (Macmillan, 1935) * Greider, William. ''Secrets of the temple: How the Federal Reserve runs the country'' (Simon and Schuster, 1989) * Meltzer, Allan H. ''A History of the Federal Reserve'' (2 vol, University of Chicago Press, 2010) == External links == * [http://www.newyorkfed.org Federal Reserve Bank of New York] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=ueQDAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA10-PA34&dq=Popular+Science+1935+plane+%22Popular+Mechanics%22&hl=en&ei=Mps3Ts_RNKL_sQLdiN0q&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q&f=true "World's Greatest Treasure Cave"] ''Popular Mechanics'', January 1930, pp. 34–38 * [https://books.google.com/books?id=S-QDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA458&dq=Popular+Mechanics+1931+%22all-metal%22&hl=en&ei=IFbvTPzWGcOanAfeg_yKCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Popular%20Mechanics%201931%20%22all-metal%22&f=true "How Uncle Sam Guards His Millions", March 1931, Popular Mechanics] article showing the upgrades for gold storage at the New York Federal Reserve Bank * [https://fraser.stlouisfed.org/theme/26 Historical resources by and about the Federal Reserve Bank of New York] including annual reports back to 1915 {{Federal Reserve System}} {{Federal Reserve Banks}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Federal Reserve Bank Of New York}} [[Category:Federal Reserve Banks|New York]] [[Category:Economy of New York City]] [[Category:Financial District, Manhattan]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Felix Haas | honorific_suffix = | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pronunciation = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name above --> | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people supply only the year with {{Birth year and age|YYYY}} unless the exact date is already widely published, as per [[WP:DOB]]. For people who have died, use {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}}. --> | birth_place = Munich, Germany | baptised = <!-- will not display if birth_date is entered --> | disappeared_date = <!-- {{disappeared date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (disappeared date then birth date) --> | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | burial_place = <!-- may be used instead of resting_place and resting_place_coordinates (displays "Burial place" as label) --> | burial_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = German | other_names = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = Technical University of Munich | occupation = | years_active = | era = | employer = | organization = | agent = <!-- Discouraged in most cases, specifically when promotional, and requiring a reliable source --> | known_for = | notable_works = <!-- produces label "Notable work"; may be overridden by |credits=, which produces label "Notable credit(s)"; or by |works=, which produces label "Works" --> | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | height = <!-- "X cm", "X m" or "X ft Y in" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | weight = <!-- "X kg", "X lb" or "X st Y lb" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source; do not add a religious denomination here --> | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | criminal_charge = <!-- Criminality parameters should be supported with citations from reliable sources --> | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = <!-- Use article title or common name --> | partner = <!-- (unmarried long-term partner) --> | children = | parents = <!-- overrides mother and father parameters --> | mother = <!-- may be used (optionally with father parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | father = <!-- may be used (optionally with mother parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | relatives = | family = | callsign = | awards = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''Felix Haas''' is a [[Germans|German]] [[entrepreneur]] and [[investor]] based in [[Munich]]. He is most known for founding [[Amiando]] and IDnow.<ref name=ALL/> He is also the co-organizer and host of [[Bits & Pretzels]], Germany’s largest founders' event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.starting-up.de/geld/investoren/business-angels-praesentieren-sich-folge-1.html|title= Im Porträt: Business Angel Felix Haas|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref>
Haas founded his first company, TiberiumSun Networks, in 1997, while still in high school. After completing his education and spending two years in [[Silicon_Valley|Silicon Valley]], he co-founded [[Amiando|Amiando]] in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dld-conference.com/users/felix-haas|title=Felix Haas|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> The company was acquired by [[XING]] in 2010 and Haas co-founded IDnow in 2013. He is an active business angel investor. He has invested in over 50 internet startups in Germany and serves on the board of several companies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.informilo.com/2015/06/germanys-crazy-gang-the-first-wave-of-entrepreneurs/|title= Germany’s Crazy Gang: The First Wave Of Entrepreneurs|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref>
== Education and early career == Haas was born and raised in Munich, Germany. While he was in high school, he actively attended computer and technology fairs. At a computer fair in Munich, he had the idea to develop a global content platform focused on computer games, movie and music. After working several weeks on designing the website, he launched tiberiumsun.com and founded TiberiumSun Entertainment in 1997.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tiberiumweb.org/history.php|title= Site History|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> Haas completed his high school in 2000 and joined [[Technical University of Munich]] for B.Sc. in Electrical Engineering and Information Technology.<ref name=ALL>{{cite web|url=http://www.gruenderszene.de/allgemein/idnow-haas-amiando|title=Das ist das neue Startup der Amiando-Gründer|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref>
While studying at Technical University of Munich, Haas joined [[BMW]] as an intern and worked with the company in Munich and the USA. After completing his B.Sc., he enrolled for M.Sc. at Technical University of Munich and received his degree in 2006. During his MS.c., he also worked as a project supervisor on a collaborative project between BMW and [[Stanford University]] in [[Palo Alto]]. He was working on the BMW team that created [[Google Maps]] "Send to Car" and he co-authored the patent describing the link between internet mapping services like Google Maps and automobiles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nextconf.eu/person/felix-haas/ |title=Felix Haas|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref>
== Career == In 2006, Haas founded Felix Haas Investments to invest in start ups in Germany. Later in 2006, he co-founded Amiando, an online platform for event registration and ticketing.<ref name=TA/> The company became very successful over the ensuing years and powered most of Europe’s technology events including LeWeb, DLD or Online Marketing Rockstars. Amiando received wide recognition for its innovative approach in event ticketing as well for its innovative business model. In 2010, Amiando was awarded Global Technology Pioneer status by the [[World Economic Forum]]. It was later sold to [[XING]] the same year.<ref name=TA>{{cite web|title =Amiando Co-Founder Marc Bernegger: Key Insights as a Serial Internet Entrepreneur | url =https://www.techinasia.com/amiando-marc-bernegger | accessdate =20 January 2016}}</ref>
Haas left the position of CEO after the acquisition of Amiando and began focusing on investing in startups. In later 2012, he became a founding investor [[Kreditech]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kreditech.com/what-we-do/|title=What We Do|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> a big data infrastructure that allows for credit bureau independent acquisition, identification, scoring and retention management in consumer lending. The next year, together with his former Amiando co-founders, he co-founded IDnow,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gruenderszene.de/allgemein/idnow-neues-ident-verfahren-esign |title=Münchner IDnow lässt Verträge per Smartphone unterschreiben}}</ref> the first online solution for convenient and secure online identification of government IDs in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/06/18/idnow-scans-holograms-in-id-cards-to-verify-your-identity-online/ |title= IDnow Scans Holograms In ID Cards To Verify Your Identity Online |accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref>
Since January 2015, Haas co-organizes and hosts Bits & Pretzels, a three-day founders' event, during Munich's Oktoberfest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gruender.wiwo.de/bits-pretzels-endlich-muss-ich-muenchner-nicht-mehr-in-berlin-treffen/2/ |title= Bits & Pretzels Endlich Muss Ich Muenchner Nicht Mehr In Berlin Treffen|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> Through Felix Haas Investments, he has invested in over 50 internet startups including JustBook,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theheureka.com/justbook-funding-round|title= Exclusive: Amiando's Felix Haas and DailyDeal's Heilemann Brothers Invest Six-Digit-Figure in JustBook|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> Iwoca,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gruenderszene.de/allgemein/felix-haas-iwoca-brille24-point-nine-capital-honey-netto-deliveroo|title= Felix Haas investiert in Iwoca – und weitere News|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> Whow Games, Jodel and Kaeuferportal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.noah-conference.com/company/felix-haas-investments/ |title=Felix Haas Investments|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> He is frequently invited to speak at Internet conferences and universities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deutsche-startups.de/2015/08/27/angel-investing-ist-ein-bisschen-wie-poker-spielen/ |title=Angel Investing ist ein bisschen wie Poker spielen|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref>
=== Not-for-Profit activities === In 2013, he was appointed as an advisor to the German Federal Ministry of Economics and Technology. In this role, he has been an advisor to the German Vice Chancellor and Minister, [[Sigmar Gabriel]] and a Member of official Advisory Group "Young Digital Economy".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theheureka.com/philipp-roesler-silicon-valley-jan-2013 |title= Germany's Economics Minister Makes Lightning Visit to Silicon Valley |accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> He also served on the board of Venturate, a platform for early-stage seed-financing for startups.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.venturate.com/startups |title=Gründe für Start-ups über Venturate Crowdfunding zu betreiben|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Haas, Felix}} [[Category:German businesspeople]] [[Category:Technical University of Munich alumni]] [[Category:Living people]]
