[[Charles Payne (journalist)|Charles Payne]] | country = [[United States]] | location = [[New York City]] | language = [[English Language|English]] | first_aired = October 15, 2007 | last_aired = March 28, 2014 | related = ''[[Countdown to the Closing Bell]]''
''[[After the Bell]]'' | website = http://video.foxbusiness.com/playlist/on-air-markets-now/ }} '''''Markets Now''''' is a daily business programming block that is aired weekdays from 11am-3pm [[Eastern Time]] on the [[Fox Business Network]]. ==About the program== ''Markets Now'' covers the day's market action, including real-time market coverage, breaking business news, and instant analysis. On May 12, 2008, the network replaced the final two hours of the block with two new programs, which debuted on the same day, ''[[Countdown to the Closing Bell]]'' (hosted by Liz Claman) and ''Fox Business After the Bell'' (formerly ''Fox Business Bulls and Bears'', hosted by Claman and David Asman). Following the launch of ''[[Opening Bell with Maria Bartiromo]]'' in February 2014,{{cite news | url=https://variety.com/2014/tv/news/fox-business-to-launch-new-daytime-schedule-feb-24-as-bartiromo-debuts-1201088208/ | title=Fox Business To Launch New Daytime Schedule Feb. 24 As Bartiromo Debuts | author=Steinberg, Brian | publisher=''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' | accessdate=March 22, 2014 | date=February 5, 2014}} ''Markets Now'' was reduced from its previous four-hour slot to one hour with [[Cheryl Casone]]. It will eventually be replaced by ''Risk and Reward'' hosted by [[Deirdre Bolton]] premiering on March 31, 2014.{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2014/tv/news/fox-business-to-launch-new-deirdre-bolton-program-march-31-1201137955/ | title=Fox Business To Launch New Deirdre Bolton Program March 31 | author=Steinberg, Brian | publisher=''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' | accessdate=March 22, 2014 | date=March 18, 2014}} The Show Markets Now ended after several months of agony on March 27, 2014. ==Personalities== ===Anchors=== {| |valign=top width=150| ====11am-noon ET==== * [[Dagen McDowell]] * [[Connell McShane]] |valign=top width=150| ====noon-1pm ET==== * [[Cheryl Casone]] * [[Dennis Kneale]] |valign=top width=150| |valign=top width=150| ====1-3pm ET==== * [[Tracy Byrnes]] * [[Ashley Webster]] |} ====Reporters==== {| |valign=top width=150| * [[Dominic Di-Natale]] * [[Jeff Flock]] * [[Charlie Gasparino]] * [[Robert Gray (TV reporter)|Robert Gray]] * [[Charles Payne (journalist)|Charles Payne]] * [[Louise Pennell]] |valign=top width=150| * [[Nicole Petallides]] * [[Sandra Smith (reporter)|Sandra Smith]] * [[Ronald McDonald]] |} ====Contributors==== * [[Scott Bleier]] * [[John "Bradshaw" Layfield]] * [[Gary B. Smith]] * [[Tobin Smith]] * [[Meredith Whitney]] ==See also== * [[CNBC]] **The following are this program's competitors from CNBC: :: ''[[Squawk on the Street]]'' (9a-noon ET) :: ''Fast Money Halftime Report'' (noon-1p ET) :: ''[[Power Lunch]]'' (1p-2p ET) :: ''[[Street Signs (CNBC)|Street Signs]]'' (2p-3p ET) :: ''[[Closing Bell]]'' (3p-5p ET) * [[Bloomberg Television]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Fox Business Shows}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Markets Now)}} [[Category:Fox Business Network programs]] [[Category:2007 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2000s American television series]] [[Category:2010s American television series]] [[Category:2014 American television series endings]] [[Category:American television news programs]] [[Category:American television talk shows]] [[Category:Business-related television series]] {{nonfiction-tv-prog-stub}} {{news-tv-prog-stub}} {{US-tv-prog-stub}}

revision.comment: linking Ames family
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Mary Shreve (Ames) Frothingham | alt = | image = Mary Frothingham.jpg | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1867|02|01}} | birth_place = [[Easton, Massachusetts]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1955|05|05|1867|02|01}} | known_for = | signature = | parents = [[Frederick Lothrop Ames]], Rebecca C. Blair | relatives = [[Oliver Ames, Sr.]] great-grandfather
[[Frederick Lothrop Ames Jr.]] brother
[[Oakes Ames]] great-uncle
}} '''Mary Shreve (Ames) Frothingham''' (February 1, 1867 - May 5, 1955) was born into the prominent [[Ames family]] of Easton, Massachusetts. She held crucial roles in the development of many local and nationally recognized organizations through leadership and financial contributions. She assumed modesty in her personal life so as to give generously to others. Her legacy in her hometown can still be enjoyed by many at the [[Ames Free Library]], Unity Church, Frothingham Hall, Frothingham Park and her home ‘Wayside’. == Family == Mary was the daughter of [[Frederick Lothrop Ames]] of Easton, Massachusetts (June 8, 1835 - September 13, 1893) and Rebecca Caroline (Blair) Ames of St. Louis Missouri (December 30, 1839 - January 20, 1903). She was the granddaughter of [[Oliver Ames Jr.]] (President of the Union Pacific Railroad 1868-1871) and great granddaughter of [[Oliver Ames Sr.]] who founded the Ames Shovel Works in 1803.Chaplin 2004, p.441 == Political Career and Marriage == In 1905, she was a member of the Massachusetts Association Opposed to the Further Extension of Suffrage and became President.Varella 1978, p.1 This was in direct conflict with her cousin-in-law [[Blanche Ames Ames|Blanche Ames]], President of the Easton Woman Suffrage League and Treasurer of the Massachusetts Woman Suffrage League. The two family members maintained a very genial relationship regardless, agreeing to disagree. For example, when the 19th Amendment passed in 1920, Blanche would often consult with Mary on whom to vote for in the coming elections. On May 8, 1916, she married [[Louis A. Frothingham]] (March 4, 1871 - August 23, 1928) at Unity Church in Easton, Massachusetts.Varella 1978, p.1 Born in Jamaica Plain, Massachusetts, Frothingham served as Major in the United States Army during World War 1. He graduated from Harvard Law in 1896, was Speaker of the Massachusetts House of Representatives and 41st Lieutenant Governor of Massachusetts (1909-1912). In 1918, Mr. Frothingham was sent to France by Governor [[Samuel W. McCall]]. While stationed in Paris, Mr. and Mrs. Frothingham opened their home to soldiers on leave and even attended to troops at the front line in the trenches. When Mr. Frothingham was running for Massachusetts 14th Congressional district in 1920, Mary served as Chairperson of the Woman’s Republican Town Committee in Easton.Varella 1978, p.3 == Community Involvement == [[File:Mary Forthingham rose garden.jpg|thumb|Mary Frothingham rose garden]] Having met [[Clara Barton]] as a young woman and establishing a longtime friendship, Mary involved herself with the [[Red Cross]]. She established the Easton branch and was President from World War I through World War II. Frothingham Hall, dedicated to her husband, served the efforts of the Red Cross through all day knitting and sewing sessions. Volunteers made coats, sweaters, pajamas and repaired bandages.Varella 1978, p.8-9 She was first President of the [[American Legion Auxiliary]] of Easton in 1920 and maintained an interest in the support of veterans and peace groups throughout her life.Varella 1978, p.3 Her devotion to the Unity Church of Easton, Massachusetts was noteworthy. Along with her mother and siblings Oliver, Frederick, John and Helen, she gave the oak screen and pulpit at the front of the church and also the [[Charles Jay Connick]] stained glass window above the main entrance. The oak carving is that of artist [[Johannes Kirchmayer]] and designed by Boston architect Henry Vaughan. She was Trustee of the Village Cemetery, located behind the church, from 1900 to 1954.Varella 1978, p.8 The [[Ames Free Library]] in North Easton, MA benefited greatly from Mary’s involvement and care. Beginning in 1900, she frequented the library often and would update any technology to suit modern day needs. For example, she introduced and paid for the first new typewriter and card catalog. She served as President of the Library from 1929 to 1955. Her portrait is hanging in the library to this day.Varella 1978, p.8 During World War I, she gave each child in town, grades 4 through 12, a thrift card and stamp to foster as interest in patriotism during wartime. She hosted a Christmas party each year for the grammar school students in Easton and provided a gift for each one. The event was held every Christmas for forty years and was reduced to only serving North Easton Grammar School kindergarten after her death. It was eventually phased out as the population and number of schools increased. She installed lockers and showers in the Anna C. Ames Gymnasium, assumed mortgages on homes in Easton that were considered a great risk and paid for the cost of dormitory life at [[Bridgewater State University]] for the daughter of her estate superintendent.Ames E. 2011, p.43Varella 1978, p.7 Her affection for gardens and public parks was evident in her charitable contributions and causes she supported. The garden at her home was large and well-kept. She commissioned landscape architect Herbert J. Kellaway to design the layout. Harriett Risley Foote, celebrated rosarian, selected the roses and supervised their planting. In 1924, the American Rose Society honored her rose garden with a visit during their annual meeting. In addition, she encouraged a home garden program for local school children. She donated to the [[Arnold Arboretum]] in Boston and she was one of the few patrons allowed to drive through the park. Frothingham Park, a memorial to her husband’s baseball career as Captain at Harvard, was dedicated on September 27, 1930. The YMCA and Oliver Ames High School utilized the park for sporting events until the 1980s. There stands a playground for young children, a baseball field surrounded by a track and tennis courts.Ames D. 2017, p.72-79Boston Transcript 1924, p.3Varella 1978, p.4-5 ==Wayside== [[File:Mary's home, Wayside (Easton town offices).jpg|thumb|Mary's home, Wayside (Easton town offices)]] Her Georgian Revival style mansion known as ’Wayside’ was built in 1912. Designed by Boston architect [[Guy Lowell]], Wayside now serves as the Easton town offices.Varella 1978, p.1 == Personal== Following the sudden death of her husband, G.O.P. leaders requested that Mary become a candidate to the 14th district office of representative in Congress. She declined the offer, citing her love of North Easton and her family and desire to remain devoted to local organizations.Brockton Enterprise 1928 == References == {{reflist}} == Bibliography == * {{Citation | title = American Rose Society to Visit Louis A. Frothingham Estate at North Easton | newspaper = Boston Evening Transcript | publication-place = Boston, MA | date = September 20, 1924 | page = 3 }} * {{Citation | title = GOP Leaders to Urge Candidacy of Mrs. Frothingham | newspaper = Brockton Enterprise | publication-place = Brockton, MA | date = August 25, 1928 | page = 1 }} * {{Citation | title = Mrs. Frothingham Not Candidate for Office | newspaper = Brockton Enterprise | publication-place = Brockton, MA | date = August 28, 1928 | page = 1 }} * {{Citation | last = Ames Jr. | first = David | title = Celebrating Seventy-Five Years and Counting | journal = Easton Historical Society: Reminiscences | volume = 8 | year = 2017 | pages = 72–79}} * {{Citation | last = Ames | first = Elizabeth M. | title = Memories of Ames Relatives | journal = Easton Historical Society: Reminiscences | volume = 2 | year = 2011 | page = 43}} * Chaplin, Ann T. (2004),''Descendents of William Ames of Braintree, Massachusetts'', Newbury Street Press {{ISBN|0-88082-182-5}}. * {{Cite | last = Varella | first = Hazel L. | title = Wayside: The Home of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Frothingham | publisher = Easton Historical Society | date = 1978 }} ==External links== *[http://www.easton.k12.ma.us/our_schools/oliver_ames_high_school/students/mary_shreve_ames_frothingham.php/ OA High School Hall of Fame 2011] *[https://tclf.org/pioneer/harriett-risley-foote/ Harriett Risley Foote] *[http://www.rose.org/ American Rose Society] *[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/52858464/mary-shreve-frothingham/ find a grave] *[http://www.redcross.org/ Red Cross] {{DEFAULTSORT:Ames, Col. David}} [[Category:1867 births]] [[Category:1955 deaths]] [[Category:Butler–Ames family]]

revision.comment: /* Controversy */
revision.text:
{{Infobox Museum |name= New York City Police Museum |image= New-york-city-police-museum.JPG |established= 1999 |location= |website= [http://www.nycpm.org www.nycpm.org] {{Infobox NRHP | name = First Police Precinct Station House | embed = yes | nrhp_type = | image = | caption = | location= | coordinates = {{coord|40|42|12|N|74|0|31|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin =Lower Manhattan#New York#USA | map_label = New York City Police Museum | built = 1909 | architect = Hunt & Hunt | architecture = Late 19th And 20th Century Revivals | added = October 29, 1982 | area = less than one acre | governing_body = Local | refnum = 82001193<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> }} }} The '''New York City Police Museum (NYCPM)''' features the history and contributions of the [[New York City Police Department]], established in 1845. The museum is located in [[Lower Manhattan]] in [[New York City]], near [[Wall Street]] and the [[South Street Seaport]]. While one of the museum's primary focuses is a memorial to [[September 11, 2001 attacks|September 11th]],<ref name="mize">{{Cite web|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SAEC&p_theme=saec&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F0B3CF7C02BF06B&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=New York Police Museum will Memorialize Sept. 11|accessdate=2008-06-11|date=2001-12-28|author=Verenea Dobnik|work=San Antonio Express-News}}</ref> the museum contains a wide range of information on the history of the NYPD. The museum, which grew from a gallery housed at the [[New York City Police Academy]], opened at [[26 Broadway]] at [[Bowling Green (New York City)|Bowling Green]] in January 2000 and re-opened in a new location at 100 Old Slip, former home of the First Precinct, in January 2002. In October 2012, Hurricane Sandy caused substantial damage at 100 Old Slip, and the museum reopened on October 24, 2013 at 45 Wall Street. That location closed in 2014 and the museum's future plans are unclear.<ref>The New York City Police Museum, http://www.nycpm.org</ref>
It also allows visitors to simulate a police firefight, and judges whether or not the shooting was correct,<ref name="blocks">{{Cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-49151233.html|title=Police Museum Opens Blocks from World Trade Center site|accessdate=2008-06-11|publisher=Associated Press|date=2001-12-27|author=Verena Dobnik}}</ref> allowing civilians to have some understanding of situations that police face and provide them with a better understanding of the work of police officers than that provided by the media. Its exhibits are not without controversy, and city historians have accused the museum of omitting coverage of more controversial aspects of NYPD history.
==Planning== [[Image:New York City Police Museum Exhibition (WTM by official-ly cool 016).jpg|right|thumb|Police uniforms on display in the museum]]
On February 16, 1998, plans for a police museum were unveiled when then-[[Police commissioner|Police Commissioner]] [[Howard Safir]] and the Alliance for Downtown New York (the local [[Business improvement district]]) made $5 million available for the museum in return for a new police substation in [[Lower Manhattan]].<ref name="briefh">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/2001/04/22/2001-04-22_brief_history_of_the_new_yor.html|title=Brief History of the New York City Police Museum|accessdate=2008-06-11|date=2001-04-22|work=New York Daily News}}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Funding for the museum was criticized and classified by some as the buying of police protection for a given area at the expense of another that could not afford to broker a similar deal. As a result, [[Mayor of New York City|Mayor]] [[Rudy Giuliani]] cancelled the funding for the museum two days later.<ref name="burn"/> In March of the same year, the New York City Police Museum [[non-profit]] corporation was created, and in April 1999, the museum opened, although the official unveiling was not held until January 19, 2000.<ref name="briefh"/>
==Broadway location== As of its January 2000 opening, the museum was privately run with support from the city, including more than ten years of free rent<ref name="burn"/> and staffing by police officers.<ref name="downt">{{Cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9503E2D9153DF933A15752C0A9669C8B63|title=City Police Museum Opens Downtown|accessdate=2008-06-11|date=2000-01-20|author=Jayson Blair|work=The New York Times}}</ref> Private donors provided more than $2 million for the construction of the museum, while the city contributed $1 million.<ref name="burn"/> The museum has been criticized by some who believe it glosses over some of the low moments of the department in its quest to show the good work of the Department.<ref name="burn">{{Cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9900EEDE1E3DF930A15752C0A9669C8B63|title= New York's 'Finest': A Burnished History; Police Museum's Unabashed Mission Is to Back Up a Nickname|accessdate=2008-06-11|date=2000-01-23|author=Kevin Flynn|work=The New York Times}}</ref>
The new museum replaced a small gallery that had been housed in the police academy on East 20th Street. Among the exhibits brought to the new museum are: a display of the evolution of police uniforms since their inception in 1853, a gun used by [[Al Capone]]'s gang in the 1928 murder of [[Frankie Yale]], the first machine gun used in a [[gangland killing]] in New York,<ref name="show"/> and a gift from [[Italy]] to the City of New York following the assassination of Lieutenant Joseph Petrosino in [[Sicily]] in 1909, the only member of NYPD to be killed in the line of duty on foreign soil.<ref name="burn"/> Other exhibits include a green and white radio car, antique [[firearm]]s and a wooden desk from the 46th Precinct in [[Morris Heights, Bronx|Morris Heights]], [[The Bronx]].<ref name="show">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/2000/01/20/2000-01-20_finest_show_in_town_cops_pre.html|title=Finest Show in Town|accessdate=2008-06-11|date=2000-01-20|author=John Marzulli|work=New York Daily News}}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Old Slip location== [[File:NYCPM van jeh.jpg|thumb|left|Patrol Wagon on display outside]] In January 2002, the museum re-opened in a new location on Old Slip, closer to [[South Street Seaport]]. The new premises, appropriately, were the old First Precinct Building, designed by the partnership of [[Richard Howland Hunt]] and [[Joseph Howland Hunt]]<ref>The brothers, who established their partnership in 1901, and were better known for their elegant Long Island and Newport residences, were the sons of [[Richard Morris Hunt]].</ref> and built in 1909-11. The [[List of New York City Designated Landmarks in Manhattan below 14th Street|landmarked]] building<ref>[http://nycnpc.org/db/bb_files/77FIRSTPOLICEPRECINCT.pdf Landmarks Preservation Commission: First Precinct Police station, 20 September 1977] Accessed 2 December 2008.</ref> was a model precinct house in its time.<ref>[http://www.nyc-architecture.com/LM/LM026-FIRSTPRECINCT,NYPD.htm New York Architectural Images: First Precinct Building].</ref> From 1884 to 1973 this Florentine Renaissance palazzo with its bold [[Rustication (architecture)|rusticated]] facades was the home of the First Precinct, which one historian called "the most important police precinct in the world."<ref name="display">{{Cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B02E0DF1231F935A15751C1A9679C8B63|title=On Display, Once Again, Artifacts of Police Past|accessdate=2008-06-11|date=2001-12-26|author=Robert F. Worth|work=The New York Times}}</ref> That precinct closed due to a corruption scandal in 1977,<ref name="fox5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,41647,00.html|title=Police Museum Opens Blocks from World Trade Center|accessdate=2008-06-11|publisher=Fox News|date=2001-12-26}}</ref> and museum officials saw a move to this location as an opportunity to connect with the department's history. Construction and renovation of the new space cost more than $4 million and exhibition space grew by nearly 45%<ref name="returnd">{{Cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0DE6D91E3DF932A05754C0A9679C8B63|title= Old Station House Returns to Police Duty; Headquarters of First Precinct Until 1973 Will House the Police Museum|accessdate=2008-06-11|date=2001-07-31|author=David W. Dunlap|work=The New York Times}}</ref>
[[File:NYPD museum Gov Is jeh.jpg|thumb|Temporary museum, pending repairs]] Its new exhibits included a 1972 [[Plymouth Fury]], a model of a jail cell, a timeline of transportation,<ref name="loiter">{{Cite web|url=http://travel.nytimes.com/2007/02/04/travel/04weekend.html?fta=y|title=Loitering in the Halls of Justice|accessdate=2008-06-11|date=2007-02-04|author=Seth Kugel|work=The New York Times}}</ref> lock-picking tools belonging to [[Willie Sutton]], an extensive exhibit on September 11 that occupies the museum's third floor, and a [[Hall of fame|Hall of Heroes]] that includes the name and badge of every NYPD officer killed in the line of duty, starting with David Martin on August 6, 1861.<ref name="display"/> Although the new museum was significantly larger, it is still not comprehensive, its omissions of controversial incidents receiving the same criticism it did at its previous location.<ref name="fox5"/> The exhibit that the museum assembled for the first anniversary of the September 11 attacks allowed visitors to gain an immediate impression of the physical damage caused by the attacks and the debris that fell around [[World Trade Center site|Ground Zero]].<ref name="911out">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/2002/09/09/2002-09-09_9_11_display_stands_out_jarr.html|title=9/11 Display Stands Out|accessdate=2008-06-11|date=2002-09-09|author=Clem Richardson|work=New York Daily News}}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Controversy==
The museum has been mired in controversy since its start. Then-police chief [[Howard Safir]] faced criticism for a deal, later rejected, with a business group that offered to pay for renovations at the museum in exchange for a police substation in the financial district.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/04/21/nyregion/police-museum-has-its-staff-overhauled.html|title=Police Museum Has Its Staff Overhauled|first=William K.|last=Rashbaum|publisher=}}</ref> Originally Safir staffed the museum with 17 paid officers; by 2001, that number was cut to nine.
In 2001, museum director Sgt. Thomas Gambino and a lieutenant were revealed to be driving expensive automobiles leased by the museum, a private institution. They were also using prime office space near the museum at without paying rent, another violation of police regulations that prohibit officers from accepting gifts.<ref name="auto"/> They and along with several officers were reassigned to other police duties.
==See also== * [[List of museums and cultural institutions in New York City]] * [[New York City Police Department]] * [[32 Old Slip]] and [[55 Water Street]], which are nearby buildings {{Clear}} {{Portal bar|New York City|New York|Law enforcement/Law enforcement topics}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{Commons category inline|New York City Police Museum}} *{{official website|http://www.nycpm.org}} {{navboxes|list= {{New York City Police Department}} {{New York City Historic Sites}} {{National Register of Historic Places in New York}} {{Museums in Manhattan|state=collapsed}} }}
[[Category:Museums in Manhattan]] [[Category:New York City Police Department|Museum]] [[Category:Law enforcement museums in the United States]] [[Category:Landmarks in Manhattan]] [[Category:Government buildings on the National Register of Historic Places in Manhattan]] [[Category:Financial District, Manhattan]] [[Category:Government buildings completed in 1909]] [[Category:Museums established in 1999]] [[Category:1999 establishments in New York (state)]]

revision.comment: /* History and description */The Feast of San Genaro was portrayed in Godfather II, not Godfather III
revision.text:
{{about||the Keren Ann album|Nolita (album)|the Italian fashion designer|No.l.ita|the unincorprated area between Santa Barbara and Goleta, CA|Noleta}} {{coord|40.722542|N|73.9951515|W|display=title|format=dms}} [[File:Mott Between Houston and Prince 13 July 2003.JPG|thumb|right|upright=1.15|[[Mott Street (Manhattan)|Mott Street]] between [[Houston Street (Manhattan)|Houston]] and Prince Streets]] [[File:Puck Building.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.15|The [[Puck Building]]]] '''Nolita''', sometimes written as '''NoLIta''', and deriving from "'''No'''rth of [[Little Italy, Manhattan|'''L'''ittle '''Ita'''ly]]"Roberts, Sam. [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/22/nyregion/22littleitaly.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=%22north%20of%20little%20italy%22&st=cse "New York’s Little Italy, Littler by the Year"] ''[[New York Times]]'' (February 21, 2011)Hughes, C.J. [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/04/realestate/04post.html?scp=1&sq=%22north%20of%20little%20italy%22&st=cse "Bigger Condos, North of Littler Italy"] ''[[New York Times]]'' (May 4, 2008)According to the [[Italian American Museum]] on [[Mulberry Street (Manhattan)|Mulberry Street]], it stands for "NOrthern Little ITAly" {{cite news |title=The food battle for New York's Little Italy |first=David |last=Farley |url=http://www.latimes.com/travel/la-tr-littleitaly-20110904,0,3935506.story |newspaper=The Los Angeles Times |date=September 4, 2011 |accessdate=2011-09-06}} is a neighborhood in the [[borough]] of [[Manhattan]] in [[New York City]]. Nolita is bounded on the north by [[Houston Street (Manhattan)|Houston Street]], on the east by the [[Bowery]], on the south roughly by [[Broome Street (Manhattan)|Broome Street]], and on the west by [[Lafayette Street (Manhattan)|Lafayette Street]]. It lies east of [[SoHo]], south of [[NoHo, Manhattan|NoHo]], west of the [[Lower East Side, Manhattan|Lower East Side]], and north of [[Little Italy, Manhattan|Little Italy]] and [[Chinatown, Manhattan|Chinatown]].[http://nymag.com/realestate/articles/neighborhoods/noho.htm "Neighborhood Profile: Nolita & Little Italy"] on the ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine website ==History and description== {{POV section|date=July 2018}} The neighborhood was long regarded as part of Little Italy, but has lost its recognizable Italian character in recent decades because of rapidly rising rents. Most of the longtime residents despise the portmanteau that was forced on the neighborhood by the real estate conglomerates and the media. Many elderly descendants of Italian immigrants continue to be pushed out of the neighborhood by greedy landlords that circumvent the rent control laws . Moreover, the [[Feast of San Gennaro]], dedicated to [[Saint Januarius]] ("pope of Naples"), is held in the neighborhood every year following Labor Day, on Mulberry Street between Houston and Grand Streets.{{cite web|title=About San Gennaro|url=http://www.sangennaro.org/about.htm|work=Feast of San Gennaro|accessdate=5 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115220557/http://sangennaro.org/about.htm|archivedate=15 January 2013|df=}} Historically most of the vendors that participated in the "Feast" lived in the neighborhood, but over the past 10 years have been replaced by mid-west style carnival touts. The feast, as recreated on Elizabeth Street between Prince and Houston, was featured in the film ''[[The Godfather Part II]]''. In the second half of the 1990s, the neighborhood saw an influx of [[yuppie]]s and an explosion of expensive retail boutiques and trendy restaurants and bars. After previous unsuccessful tries to pitch the neighborhood as part of SoHo, real estate promoters and others came up with several different names for consideration of this newly upscale neighborhood. The name that stuck, as documented in an article on May 5, 1996 in the ''[[New York Times]]'' City Section debating various monikers for the newly trendy area, was ''Nolita'', an abbreviation for '''No'''rth of '''L'''ittle '''Ita'''ly. This name follows the [[portmanteau]] pattern started by [[SoHo]] ('''So'''uth of '''Ho'''uston Street), and [[TriBeCa]] ('''Tri'''angle '''Be'''low '''Ca'''nal Street). The neighborhood includes [[St. Patrick's Old Cathedral]], at the intersection of Mulberry, Mott and Prince Streets, which opened in 1815 and was rebuilt in 1868 after a fire.{{cite nycland}}, p.42 The cornerstone was laid on June 8, 1809. This building served as New York City's [[Roman Catholic]] cathedral until the new [[St. Patrick's Cathedral (Manhattan)|St. Patrick's Cathedral]] was opened on [[Fifth Avenue]] in [[Midtown Manhattan|Midtown]] in 1879.Farley, John Murphy. (1908). ''History of St. Patrick's Cathedral Society for the propagation of the faith''. pp. 127–128, 130, 151. St. Patrick's Old Cathedral is now a [[parish church]]. In 2010, St. Patrick's Old Cathedral was honored and became The Basilica at St. Patrick's Old Cathedral. Another neighborhood landmark is the [[Puck Building]], an ornate structure built in 1885 on the corner of Houston and Lafayette Streets, which originally housed the headquarters of the now-defunct ''[[Puck (magazine)|Puck]]'' Magazine.[http://www.nyc-architecture.com/SOH/SOH037.htm "Puck Building"] on the ''New York Architecture'' website ==Notable residents== * Prior to his death, [[David Bowie]] and his wife, [[Iman (model)|Iman]], had a home in Nolita.[http://www.fashionmodeldirectory.com/news/Model+News/still-ties-shoes-for-iman-reveals-how-david-bowie-makes-her-feel-special.htm Iman]. Fashion Model Directory. Retrieved 9 May 2012. * Actor [[Gabriel Byrne]] lives in Nolita.Polsky, Sara (April 30, 2010). [http://ny.curbed.com/archives/2010/04/30/actor_gabriel_byrne_buys_in_nolitas_211_elizabeth.php "Actor Gabriel Byrne Buys in Nolita's 211 Elizabeth"]. [[Curbed]]. * Singer/songwriter [[Vanessa Carlton]]; her song "[[Nolita Fairytale]]" was inspired by the neighborhood.Brill, Lauren. [http://www.wnba.com/allstar2007/vanessacarlton_070711.html "One On One With Vanessa Carlton"]. [[WNBA.com]] (July 11, 2007) * Musician [[Moby]] lived in Nolita.{{cite news |title=He's Sensitive About the Pancakes |first=Lizette |last=Alvarez |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/28/nyregion/28routine.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=March 25, 2010 |accessdate=2010-07-18}} * Singer/songwriter [[John Mayer]] owns an apartment in Nolita, and it was featured in ''[[Elle Decor]]'' magazine.Hackett, Kathleen. [http://www.elledecor.com/celebrity-homes/articles/john-mayer-house "At home with John Mayer"] ''[[Elle Decor]]'' (ndg) * [[Martin Scorsese]] was born in Queens but raised in the neighborhood, on [[Elizabeth Street (Manhattan)|Elizabeth Street]] between Prince and Houston, where his grandparents (Italian immigrants) also lived. It was part of [[Little Italy, Manhattan|Little Italy]] at that time.{{cite web|url=http://www.neh.gov/about/awards/jefferson-lecture/martin-scorsese-biography |title=Martin Scorsese Biography |publisher=National Endowment for the Humanities |date= |accessdate=January 24, 2014}} ==Gallery==
File:Odd Fellows Hall 165-171 Grand Street.jpg|[[Odd Fellows Hall (New York City)|Odd Fellows Hall]] File:Saint Pats Old Cathedral Manh jeh.JPG|[[St. Patrick's Old Cathedral]] File:St. Patrick's Convent and Girls' School.jpg|[[St. Patrick's Old Cathedral School]] File:WTM3 Gnarly 0165.jpg|14th Ward Industrial School, designed by [[Calvert Vaux]] File:St. Michael's Russian Catholic Church.jpg|[[St. Patrick's Old Cathedral#Cathedral complex|St. Michael's Russian Catholic Church]]
==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Commons category-inline}} * [[Elizabeth Street Garden]] {{Manhattan}} [[Category:Little Italys in the United States]] [[Category:Neighborhoods in Manhattan]] [[Category:Italian-American culture in New York City]] [[Category:Lower Manhattan]]

revision.comment: migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/Pol Clovis Boël|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Pol-Clovis Boël | image = | image_size = 150px | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Pol-Clovis, Baron Boël | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1868|8|2}} | birth_place = [[La Louvière|Saint-Vaast]], [[Belgium]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1941|7|13|1868|8|2}} | death_place = [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] | nationality = {{BEL}} | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = industrialist, politician }} '''Pol-Clovis, Baron Boël''' (2 August 1868 – 13 July 1941) was a [[Belgium|Belgian]] industrialist, Director of the ''[[Usines Gustave Boël]]'' in [[La Louvière]], and [[liberalism|liberal]] politician.
Born in [[La Louvière|Saint-Vaast]], he was a son of [[Gustave Boël]]. He married [[Marthe de Kerchove de Denterghem]]. They had 4 children (3 boys and 1 girl): [[René Boël]] (1899–1990) married first Yvonne Solvay (1896–1930) and later Mathilde de Jonghe d'Ardoye (1909 - 2008); [[Max Boël]] (1901 - 1975) married Anne Guinotte); [[Lucien Boël]] (1903 - ) married Micheline Mallet; and their daughter [[Marie-Anne Boël]] (1909 - 1996) married [[Charles-Emmanuel Janssen]]. Pol-Clovis youngest sister [[Eva Ernestine Boël]] (1883–1956) married [[Felix Goblet d'Alviella]].
==Career== When Gustave Boël died in 1912, his son Pol-Clovis carried on the diversification of the family business. One of his most prominent successes in this area was in chemicals with the ''Société anonyme de fabrication des engrais azoté'' (Safea) ([[nitrate]] [[fertilizers]]). Pol-Clovis also invested in [[UCB (company)|Union Chimique Belge (UCB)]], founded by [[Emmanuel Janssen]] (the father of his son-in-law Charles-Emmanuel Janssen), and in [[Solvay (company)|Solvay]], founded by [[Ernest Solvay]], the grandfather of his daughter-in-law [[Yvonne Solvay]].
In 1928, Pol-Clovis Boël founded a financial entity: ''l'Union financière Boël'', ancestor of several financial holdings, such as [[Sofina]], [[Henex]], [[Glaces de Moustier-sur-Sambre]]. After World War I, \Boël entered the world of Belgian finance, taking part in the creation of the [[Bank of Brussels]] and the [[Société Générale de Belgique]]. In 1929, he was granted the title of baron by King [[Albert I of Belgium]].
Pol Clovis died in [[Brussels]] in 1941.
==Sources== * Dutrieue, Anne-Myriam, in : Kurgan-van Hentenrijk, Ginette, Jaumain, Serge, Montens, Valérie, ea, ''Dictionnaire des patrons en Belgique. Les hommes, les entreprises, les reseaux, Bruxelles'', De Boeck and Larcier, 1996, p. 61-62. * Douxchamps, José, ''Présence nobiliaire au parlement belge (1830–1970)''. Notes généalogiques, Wépion-Namen, José Douxchamps, 2003, p. 13.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Boel, Pol Clovis}} [[Category:1837 births]] [[Category:1912 deaths]] [[Category:People from La Louvière]] [[Category:Belgian businesspeople]] <!--[[Category:Liberal politicians]] Temporary, category is being considered for deletion.-->

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Use Jamaican English|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Rohan Marley | image = CES 2012 - House of Marley (Rohan Marley).jpg | caption = Marley in 2012 | birth_name = Rohan Anthony Marley | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1972|05|19}} | birth_place = [[Kingston, Jamaica]]Bruce Newman. "[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1138363 Hurricane From The Caribbean]". ''Sports Illustrated''. 13 September 1993. Retrieved on 30 April 2013. | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | occupation = Chairman of Marley Coffee
Chief Passion Officer of Gisges | spouse = Geraldine Khawly (m. 1993–1996) | partner = [[Lauryn Hill]] (1996–2009) | children = 7, including [[Nico Marley]] | parents = [[Bob Marley]]
Janet Hunt | website = {{URL|http://rohanmarley.com/}}
{{URL|http://marleycoffee.com/}}
{{URL|http://gisges.com/}} }} {{Infobox gridiron football person | name = Rohan Marley | team = | image = | alt = | caption = | status = | import = | position1 = Linebacker | number = 2 | college = [[University of Miami]] | CIS = | high_school = | height_ft = 5 | height_in = 8 | weight_lbs = 205 | CFLDraftedYear = | CFLDraftedRound = | CFLDraftedPick = | CFLDraftedTeam = | playing_years1 = 1992–1994 | playing_team1 = Miami Hurricanes | playing_years2 = 1995 | playing_team2 = Ottawa Rough Riders (CFL) }} '''Rohan Anthony Marley''' (born 19 May 1972) is an entrepreneur and former [[American football]] player. He is the son of [[reggae]] artist [[Bob Marley]] and Janet Hunt. He was born during his father's marriage to [[Rita Marley|Rita]], and went to live with her from the age of four{{cite book|last=Moskowitz|first=David Vlado|title=Bob Marley: A Biography|url=https://books.google.com/?id=aNv2XuFP2-QC&pg=PA94&lpg=PA94&dq=Bob+Marley+and+Janet+Hunt#v=onepage&q=Bob%20Marley%20and%20Janet%20Hunt&f=false|accessdate=Jan 2014|year=2007|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=0313338795|pages=94–95}}{{cite web|author=Raul|url=http://www.feelnumb.com/2011/07/26/bob-marley-and-all-his-children-baby-mommas/|title=Bob Marley All His Children & 9 Baby Mommas|date=26 July 2011|work=FeelNumb.com|accessdate=15 January 2014}} then lived with [[Cedella Booker|Marley's mother]] after his father died of cancer in Miami in 1981.[[George Vecsey]]. "[https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/29/sports/sports-of-the-times-sugar-bowl-rocks-early-with-strains-of-marley.html Sports of the Times; Sugar Bowl Rocks Early With Strains of Marley]". ''New York Times''. 29 December 1992. Retrieved on 15 Jan 2014. A 1991 graduate of [[Miami Palmetto Senior High School]],David O'Brien. "[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sun_sentinel/access/88046627.html?dids=88046627:88046627&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+03%2C+1991&author=DAVID+O%27BRIEN%2C+Staff+Writer&pub=South+Florida+Sun+-+Sentinel&desc=THIS+MARLEY%27S+MUSIC+HAS+MORE+POP+TO+IT&pqatl=google This Marley's music has more pop to it]". ''Sun Sentinel''. 3 September 1991. 1.C. Retrieved on 8 August 2009. Marley played [[linebacker]] for the [[University of Miami]] football team, where he played alongside [[Dwayne Johnson]], [[Warren Sapp]] and [[Ray Lewis]]. In 1993, he led the Hurricanes with 95 tackles. He later played professional football in the [[Canadian Football League]] with the now defunct [[Ottawa Rough Riders]]."[https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5937565/cover_story_lady_soul Lady Soul]". ''Rolling Stone''. 18 February 1999. Retrieved on 8 August 2009. ==Career== In 2009, he co-founded Marley Coffee, an organic coffee plantation and "sustainable" farming business in [[Blue Mountains (Jamaica)|Jamaica's Blue Mountains]],[http://www.marleycoffee.com/html/our_story.html Marley Coffee Website - Our Story] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100126003401/http://www.marleycoffee.com/html/our_story.html |date=26 January 2010 }} although the majority of coffee sourced through Marley Coffee is from Ethiopia. The business is run on a 52-acre estate in [[Portland Parish]].{{cite web | url=http://avahtaylor.wordpress.com/2011/06/09/a-conversation-with-rohan-marley-pt-1/ | title=Exclusive: Rohan Marley Sets the Record Straight | publisher=The Avah Taylor Company | date=9 June 2011 | accessdate=23 February 2014}} In 2011, Marley Coffee went public under the name Jammin Java Corp (OTC:JAMN). In January 2012, Marley advertised a new 'House of Marley' range of eco-friendly headphones at the [[Consumer Electronics Show]] in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], Nevada."[http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/entertainment/Marley-promotes-good-vibrations_12802745 Marley promotes good vibrations]", ''[[Jamaica Observer]]'', 21 October 2012, retrieved 27 October 2012 Marley also helps run his family's charitable organization, [[1Love]], as well as the Tuff Gong Clothing Company.{{cite web|url=http://www.iriefm.net/news/music/rohan-marley-ends-engagement%E2%80%A6|title=Rohan Marley Ends Engagement|date=2013-03-05|publisher=iriefm.net|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140712055600/http://iriefm.net/news/music/rohan-marley-ends-engagement%E2%80%A6|archivedate=12 July 2014|df=dmy-all}} He made an appearance in the documentary film [[Motherland (2010 film)|''Motherland'']].http://www.themotherland.info Motherland Film with Rohan Marley ==Personal life== On 18 March 1993, while a sophomore in college, Marley married his girlfriend Geraldine Khawly. They had a daughter, Eden, and a son, [[Nico Marley|Nico]], a linebacker who played at [[Tulane Green Wave football|Tulane]] and was signed by the [[Washington Redskins]] in 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.tulanegreenwave.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/nico_marley_838197.html |title=Tulane Green Wave Football |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140829092249/http://www.tulanegreenwave.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/nico_marley_838197.html |archivedate=29 August 2014 |df= }}{{cite web|last1=Czarda|first1=Stephen|title=Redskins Sign Linebacker Nico Marley|url=http://www.redskins.com/news/article-1/Redskins-Sign-Linebacker-Nico-Marley/69555778-b3f7-453a-8053-eac6eec15dc8|website=Redskins.com|accessdate=16 May 2017}} Marley met musician [[Lauryn Hill]] in 1996. They had five children:Laura Checkoway. "[https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/22713461/inside_the_miseducation_of_lauryn_hill/print Inside 'The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill']". ''Rolling Stone''. Augusthttp://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1264/is_3_33/ai_87741110/pg_5 Essence Magazine Zion David (b. August 1997); Selah Louise (b. September 1998); Joshua Omaru (b. 2002) John Nesta (b. 2003); and Sarah (b. 2008).{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20221692,00.html|title=Whatever Happened to ... Lauryn Hill?|date=2008-08-18|author=Tiffany McGee and Alex Tresniowski|publisher=[[People Magazine]]}} Marley and Hill lived apart for most of their relationship, which ended for good in 2009. Marley took temporary custody of their five children while Hill served a three-month prison sentence for tax evasion in 2013. For years, Hill referred to Marley as her husband, but they never married.{{cite web|url=http://themastercopy.com/2013/05/13/rohan-marley-will-take-care-of-kids-when-lauryn-goes-to-jail/ |title=Rohan Marley will take care of kids when Lauryn goes to jail |date=2013-05-13 |publisher=The Master Copy |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407092945/http://themastercopy.com/2013/05/13/rohan-marley-will-take-care-of-kids-when-lauryn-goes-to-jail/ |archivedate=7 April 2014 |df= }} ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' suggested that Marley had never divorced Khawly. However, in 2011, Marley produced a Haitian divorce decree which demonstrated that he had divorced Khawly in 1996. Marley was briefly engaged to [[Isabeli Fontana]], but the engagement ended in early 2013. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://anicetime.com/ Online home to the Marley Family] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090704214940/http://web.bobmarley.com/family/bio.jsp?id=2008022193266 Rohan Marley at BobMarley.com] * [http://www.marleycoffee.com Marley Coffee] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120215091342/http://www.1love.org/ 1Love] * [http://avahtaylor.wordpress.com/tag/rohan-marley-divorce/ Rohan Marley Divorce Document] {{Bob Marley family}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Marley, Rohan}} [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Kingston, Jamaica]] [[Category:American football linebackers]] [[Category:Jamaican Rastafarians]] [[Category:Marley family|R]] [[Category:Miami Hurricanes football players]] [[Category:Canadian football linebackers]] [[Category:Ottawa Rough Riders players]] [[Category:Jamaican players of American football]] [[Category:Jamaican businesspeople]] [[Category:Jamaican people of English descent]] [[Category:Lauryn Hill]]

{{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix = [[Doctor (title)|Dr.]] |name = Rudolf de Korte |honorific-suffix = [[Order of Orange-Nassau|CON]] |image = Rudolf de Korte 1985 (1).jpg |imagesize = 250px |caption = Rudolf de Korte in 1985 |office = [[Deputy Prime Minister of the Netherlands|Deputy Prime Minister]] |term_start = 14 July 1986 |term_end = 7 November 1989 |primeminister = [[Ruud Lubbers]] |predecessor = [[Gijs van Aardenne]] |successor = [[Wim Kok]] |office1 = [[List of Ministers of Economic Affairs of the Netherlands|Minister of Economic Affairs]] |term_start1 = 14 July 1986 |term_end1 = 7 November 1989 |primeminister1 = [[Ruud Lubbers]] |predecessor1 = [[Gijs van Aardenne]] |successor1 = [[Koos Andriessen]] |office2 = [[Leader of the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy|Leader of the People's Party
for Freedom and Democracy]] |term_start2 = 9 July 1986 |term_end2 = 15 December 1986 |predecessor2 = [[Ed Nijpels]] |successor2 = [[Joris Voorhoeve]] |office3 = [[List of Ministers of the Interior of the Netherlands|Minister of the Interior]] |term_start3 = 12 March 1986 |term_end3 = 14 July 1986 |primeminister3 = [[Ruud Lubbers]] |predecessor3 = [[Frits Korthals Altes]]
(''Ad interim'') |successor3 = [[Kees van Dijk]] |office4 = [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|Member of the House of Representatives]] |term_start4 = 14 September 1989 |term_end4 = 1 September 1995 |term_start5 = 3 June 1986 |term_end5 = 14 July 1986 |term_start6 = 22 December 1977 |term_end6 = 12 March 1986 |parliamentarygroup6= [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy|People's Party for
Freedom and Democracy]] |birthname = Rudolf Willem de Korte |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1936|07|08|df=y}} |birth_place = [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]] |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = [[Netherlands|Dutch]] |party = [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy|People's Party for
Freedom and Democracy]]
(from 1959) |spouse = {{marriage|Karin de Korte|1966}} |children = |residence = [[Wassenaar]], [[Netherlands]] |alma_mater = [[Leiden University]]
([[Bachelor of Business Administration]], [[Master of Business Administration]], [[Doctor of Philosophy]]) |occupation = [[Politician]] · [[Businessperson|Businessman]] · [[Bank|Banker]] · [[Board of directors|Corporate director]] · [[Board of directors|Nonprofit director]] · [[Author]] |signature = |website = }} '''Rudolf Willem de Korte''' (born 8 July 1936) is a retired [[Netherlands|Dutch]] politician of the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] (VVD). ==Decorations== {| class="wikitable" style="width:60%;" |- style="background:#ccf; text-align:center;" | colspan=5 |'''Honours''' |- ! style="width:80px;"| Ribbon bar !! Honour !! Country !! Date !!
