revision.text:
{{other people||Sean Gallagher (disambiguation){{!}}Sean Gallagher}} {{EngvarB|date=November 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Seán Gallagher | image = Seán Gallagher.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1962|7|7|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Monaghan]], Ireland | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Irish people|Irish]] | party = [[Independent politician|Independent]] {{small|(since 2011)}}
[[Fianna Fáil]] {{small|(until 2011)}} | known for = Co-founder of ''Smarthomes'' | television = ''[[Dragons' Den (Irish TV series)|Dragons' Den]]'' {{small|(2009–11)}}
''[[Charity Lords of the Ring]]'' {{small|(2009)}} | residence = [[Delgany]], [[County Wicklow]], Ireland | education = [[Ballyhaise College|Teagasc Agricultural College]] | alma_mater = {{Ubl|[[Maynooth University]]|[[Dundalk Institute of Technology]]|[[University of Ulster]]}} | spouse = {{marriage|Irene McCausland|1997|1999|end=div.}}
{{marriage|Patrica Gallagher|2010}} | children = 2 | parents = {{Ubl|John Gallagher|Anne Bracken}} | website = {{URL|seangallagher2018.com}} |}} '''Seán Diarmiud Gallagher''' (born 7 July 1962) is an Irish businessman and [[reality television]] personality. He was a co-founder in 2000 of Smarthomes, which after initial success, failed in 2008–2010, and Gallagher departed in 2010–11. He was as a panellist on [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]'s ''[[Dragons' Den (Irish TV series)|Dragons' Den]]'' from 2009–2011. Gallagher was an active member of [[Fianna Fáil]] for 30 years from 1981–2011, and sat on its National Executive twice (from 1985–87, and from 2009–11). He spent much of his career before Smarthomes working in Fianna Fáil, and in the Irish public service. Gallagher failed in his [[Irish presidential election, 2011|2011 presidential election]] bid, in which, despite his Fianna Fáil history, he stood as an Independent candidate, and finished second to [[Michael D. Higgins]]. He was again a candidate in the [[Irish presidential election, 2018|2018 presidential election]]; this time he achieved third place. ==Early life and education== Seán Gallagher was born in [[Monaghan]] town, [[County Monaghan]] in July 1962,{{efn |Several articles on Seán Gallagher list him incorrectly as being born in Ballyhaise, County Cavan; however, he was born in 17 Devin Reilly Terrace in Monaghan.{{cite web |url= http://www.northernstandard.ie/2011/10/21/gallagher-visits-former-family-home-in-Monaghan/ |title=Gallagher Visits Former Family Home In Monaghan |date=21 October 2011 |publisher=The Northern Standard |quote=Mr Gallagher [...] was born in 17, Devin Reilly Terrace, Monaghan on 7th July 1962. The Gallagher family lived at Devin Reilly Terrace for a number of years before moving to Ballyhaise in County Cavan.}}}}{{cite web |url=http://www.northernstandard.ie/2018/09/13/presidential-race-gallagher-gets-in-but-o-caolain-stays-out/ |title=Presidential Race – Gallagher Gets In But Ó Caoláin Stays Out |publisher=The Northern Standard |date=13 September 2018 |quote=Monaghan Town-born entrepreneur Seán Gallagher secured the four local authority nominations he needed to contest the October 26 poll to decide the next President of Ireland}} but moved a "few years later", where he was raised in a family of six in [[Ballyhaise]], [[County Cavan]].{{cite web |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/the-many-faces-of-se%C3%A1n-gallagher-1.627634 |title=The many faces of Seán Gallagher |author=Harry McGee |date=20 October 2011 |publisher=[[Irish Times]]}} Gallagher was effectively blind up until age 3 as a result of congenital cataracts. However, while corrective surgery improved his sight, Gallagher describes himself as being "visually impaired". From September 1974 to June 1980, Gallagher was educated at Saint Mary's National School in Glin and [[St Patrick's College, Cavan|Saint Patrick's College]] in [[Cavan]]. Following his [[Leaving Certificate (Ireland)|Leaving Certificate]] in June 1980, he attended [[Ballyhaise College|Teagasc Agricultural College]], in Ballyhaise, County Cavan where he received a National Certificate in Agriculture in June 1981. He said that he then worked on the college farm until a car accident in June 1983, which required a period of rehabilitation.{{efn|In interviews, Gallagher refers to his year-long recovery from the car accident as being motivated by a new-found commitment to physical fitness.{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.ie/lifestyle/through-the-eyes-of-a-dragon-26634131.html/ |title=Through the eyes of a Dragon|author=Barry Egan|publisher=Irish Independent|date=21 February 2010}}}}{{cite web |url=http://betterbusiness.ie/sean-gallagher-way-see/ |title="Better Business: Seán Gallagher" |date=2016 |publisher=BetterBusiness |quote=After school, he attended the local agricultural college. His first job was working with the college and he had a small farm for a while. Then in 1983, he was in a car accident which took him on a bit of a detour. He went back to college in Maynooth University, trained as a youth worker and spent the next several years in the public sector.}} In September 1985, Gallagher went to [[Maynooth University]] where he earned a Diploma in Youth Work and Community Development in June 1987. During his tenure as Assistant CEO{{efn|name="it"}} of the Louth Country Enterprise Board (1995–2000), Gallagher studied for a Diploma in Management in the [[Dundalk Institute of Technology]] from 1997–1999, after which Gallagher then completed an MBA in 2000, at the [[University of Ulster]].{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.ie/regionals/fingalindependent/news/sean-cares-about-ireland-and-its-people-27805639.html |title=Seán cares about Ireland and its people |date=20 October 2010 |publisher=[[Irish Independent]] |author=Anne Campbell}} ==Public service career== Much of Gallagher's early career from circa 1988 to June 2000, from when he was age 26 to when he was age 38, involved working with various Irish State bodies and departments. It is not clear whether these roles are full-time or part-time, and the non-public service activities he was engaged in (e.g. he is recorded as stating that he was a fitness instructor and massage therapist in the 1990s{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/sean-gallaghers-secret-past-revealed-he-was-an-aerobics-instructor-26783803.html|title=Seán Gallagher's secret past revealed - he was an aerobics instructor|date=16 September 2018|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]}}). From 1988 to 1990, Gallagher said he worked as a Project Co-ordinator for the [[National Youth Council of Ireland]] and the [[Department of Health (Ireland)|Department of Health]], and that he was the author of ''Drink Awareness for Young People'', Ireland's first national alcohol education programme. From 1990 to 1993, Gallagher worked as a full-time [[Political consulting|political advisor]] to then [[Fianna Fáil]] TD and [[Minister for Health (Ireland)|Minister for Health]]{{efn|name="rory"|Gallagher says in interviews that it was while he was working at the Department of Health that he met Rory O'Hanlon}} [[Rory O'Hanlon]].{{cite web|title=Our People – Board members|url=http://www.intertradeireland.com/aboutus/ourpeople/boardmembers/|work=InterTradeIreland|accessdate=27 June 2011}}{{cite web|title=Dragon's Den star Seán Gallagher on the Ógra Fianna Fáil National Youth Conference |url=http://www.fiannafail.ie/blog/entry/dragons-den-star-sean-gallagher-on-the-ogra-fianna-fail-national-youth-conf/ |accessdate=5 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110709025404/http://www.fiannafail.ie/blog/entry/dragons-den-star-sean-gallagher-on-the-ogra-fianna-fail-national-youth-conf |archivedate=9 July 2011 |df= }} After O'Hanlon lost his cabinet minister position when [[Albert Reynolds]] came to power in Fianna Fáil in 1992, Gallagher said that he was an Enterprise Officer for the [[Blanchardstown]] Area Development Partnership from 1993 to 1995. In May 1995, aged 32, Gallagher moved to Blackrock in County Louth where he served as the Assistant CEO{{efn|name="it"|The InterTradeIreland Annual report of 2007, listed Gallager as Deputy CEO of the Board from 1995-2000, however, Gallagher seems to use the term A/CEO, or Assistant CEO most often.{{cite web|url=http://www.waterford-today.ie/waterford-today-news/436-sean-gallagher-speaks-at-free-business-start-up-seminar-19605.html|title=Seán Gallagher speaks at FREE business start-up seminar|date=16 May 2011|publisher=Waterford Today|quote=Prior to becoming an entrepreneur himself, Seán was assistant CEO with the County Enterprise Boards}}}} of the Louth County Enterprise Board.{{cite news|title=Dragon Profile – Seán Gallagher|url=http://www.rte.ie/tv/dragonsden/profile_sean.html|work=RTÉ.ie|accessdate=27 June 2011}} His role was to promote and support the development of micro businesses including the provision of financial support, training and mentoring. As part of this role, he served as a Director of the Louth Tourism Company and Louth Leader Rural Development Agency. ==Business career== ===Smarthomes Limited (2000–2010)=== In June 2000, Gallagher, aged 38, left the Louth County Enterprise Board ("LCEB") to set up a company called Home Wiring Systems Limited ("HWSL") with electrical tool-maker, Derek Roddy. HWSL's plan was to provide the electrical systems modern homes needed (e.g. broadband systems, heating systems, alarm systems etc.), and HWSL would be, in effect, an electrical contractor. In 2001, HWSL got a start-up loan of €25,395 from the LCEB.{{efn|name="LCEB"|The Louth County Entreprise Bord ("LCEB") seed-loan would be a source of controversy during the 2011 Presidential election as it was revealed that Smarthomes asserted that the loan was not repayable as it was "left" in HWSL; however in an RTÉ interview during the campaign, Gallagher stated that when the LCEB asserted their rights in 2005, that a confidential settlement was reached in 2008. On 12 October 2011, Gallagher stated on RTÉ's ''Drivetime'' program that: "If I was doing it again perhaps I would have done it differently."{{cite web|url=https://www.broadsheet.ie/2011/10/13/sean-gallagher-and-the-old-switcheroo/|title=Seán Gallagher RTÉ Interview Transcript|date=13 October 2011|publisher=Broadsheet}}}} In September 2002, Gallagher and Roddy decided to re-brand HWSL and transferred HWSL into a new limited liability company, called Smarthomes Limited. Smarthomes won business awards, including the Deloitte "Fast 50 Award" in 2005, and Gallagher was a finalist in the 2006 [[Ernst & Young]] "Entrepreneur of the Year". The company raised €750,000 in loans from Business Expansion Scheme ("BES") investors in 2005, and raised another €830,000 in grant-loans from Irish State agencies during 2004-2007.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/gallagher-shared-in-payout-of-860000-26784569.html|title=Gallagher shared in payout of €860,000|date=22 October 2011|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|author1=Siobhan Creaton |author2=Cormac McQuinn}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/gallagher-s-10m-promise-fails-to-materialise-1.626864|title=Gallagher's €10m promise fails to materialise|date=19 October 2011|author=Paul Cullen|publisher=[[Irish Times]]}} Smarthomes turnover grew from circa €1 million in 2004, to circa €7 million by 2006, when it made a peak pre-tax profit of circa €500,000, a 7% margin. In December 2006, the then Fianna Fáil [[Taoiseach]] [[Bertie Ahern]] opened their new offices, at which Gallagher announced he planned to invest €10 million and create 100 jobs.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/regionals/argus/news/bertie-on-whirlwind-tour-of-louth-26907685.html|title=Bertie on whirlwind tour of Louth|date=14 December 2006|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]}} However, in 2007, the business broke–even, and in 2008, the business lost €652,000, and it lost €540,000 in 2009. Despite the losses, filed accounts showed that Gallagher and Roddy drew €542,500 from the company in 2008, and €316,000 in 2009.{{efn|name="z1"}} There were issues with the BES investors who had not realised that the company was paying rent and royalties to the Directors, however, by March 2010, they had converted their loans into equity in the company, and a new plan agreed, with the premises changed and patents returned from the Directors to the company. Gallagher left Smarthomes in 2010 and sold his shares in 2011. ''Smarthomes'' returned to modest profitability in 2011–12, and while the company was still trading in 2017, the main focus of the Directors is their ''climote'' business.{{efn|Gallagher also owned shares in ''climote'' but also sold out his holding in 2011}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/gallaghers-former-company-smarthomes-returns-to-profitability-26891765.html|title=Gallagher's former company Smarthomes returns to profitability|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|date=28 August 2012|author=Godron Deegan}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/gallagher-plays-no-part-in-smart-homes-says-md-conway-29358803.html|title=Gallagher plays no part in Smart Homes, says MD Conway|date=20 June 2013|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|author=Sarah McCabe}} ===State Boards (2007–2012)=== On 13 December 2007, Fianna Fáil [[Minister for Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation|Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment]] [[Mary Coughlan (politician)|Mary Coughlan]] appointed him to the Board of [[InterTradeIreland]], a North-South Irish trade body, until 2011.{{cite web|url=https://intertradeireland.com/app/uploads/2018/03/InterTradeIreland-Annual-Report-and-Accounts-2007.pdf|title=InterTradeIreland: Annual Report 2007|publisher=[[InterTradeIreland]]|date=December 2007|quote=Board Member: SEAN GALLAGHER}} There was some controversy that his appointment came after the successful re-election of Fianna Fáil parliamentary party Chairman, [[Séamus Kirk]], in the May 2007 general election, for whom Gallagher was Director of Elections; and also that InterTradeIreland invested €41,970 into ''Smarthomes'' in 2007, and that Gallagher had attended only 22 of the 36 Board meetings during his tenure.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/gallagher-sat-on-board-of-quango-that-gave-his-firm-cash-26782270.html | title=Gallagher sat on board of quango that gave his firm cash | date=15 October 2011 | publisher=[[Irish Independent]] | author1=Michael Brennan | author2=Eimear Ni Bhraonain | quote=He was appointed to the board of North-South body Intertrade Ireland at the end of 2007 -- and annual accounts for that year reveal they gave €41,970 to his Smart Homes company. [..] But it also emerged that he managed to miss half of all Intertrade Ireland board meetings over the past two-and-a-half years -- despite getting €30,000 in fees.}} In January 2010, after Gallagher was elected to the Fianna Fáil National Executive in 2009, Mary Coughlan appointed him to the Board of [[Foras Áiseanna Saothair|FÁS]], until 2012. In June 2010, Gallagher was also appointed by Fianna Fáil Minister for Transport, [[Noel Dempsey]], to be Chair of the Drogheda Port Company, which he held until 2012.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/sean-gallagher-reveals-41550-in-payments-from-state-boards-since-2008-26778247.html|title=Seán Gallagher reveals €41,550 in payments from State boards since 2008|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|author=Ed Carthy|date=3 October 2011}}{{cite web|url=https://www.handling-network.com/drogheda-port-sails-through-turbulent-times/|title=Drogheda Port sails through turbulent times|date=3 July 2011|quote=The company’s chairperson, Seán Gallagher, said: “I am honoured and delighted to have been appointed as Chairman of the company in 2010 at a key juncture in the port’s future development.}} ===Irish Television (2009–2016)=== In October 2008, Gallagher was announced as an investor on the [[RTÉ One]] version of ''[[Dragons' Den (Irish TV series)|Dragons' Den]]''. He continued as an investor in the 2009, 2010 and 2011 series.{{cite news|title=RTÉ's Dragons' Den seeking entrepreneurs|url=http://www.rte.ie/ten/2008/1008/dragonsden.html|accessdate=27 June 2011|work=RTÉ.ie|date=8 October 2008}} In August 2009, he took part in the ''[[Charity Lords of the Ring]]'' series, an amateur celebrity boxing reality television show, representing the [[National Council for the Blind of Ireland]], and went on to win the show and earn €17,350 for his charity.{{efn|In 2007, Gallagher listed that he was a 1st dan black-belt in both Judo and Karate}}{{cite web|title=Winner crowned in Lords of the Ring|url=http://www.rte.ie/ten/2009/0823/charitylordsofthering.html|accessdate=27 June 2011|work=RTÉ.ie|date=23 August 2009}} In March 2016, Gallagher appeared as a celebrity chef on TV3's cooking show, ''The Restaurant''.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/lifestyle/healthandlife/dietandfitness/the-shape-im-in-sean-gallagher-businessman-386494.html|publisher=[[The Irish Examiner]]|date=16 March 2016|title=The shape I'm in: Seán Gallagher, businessman}} ===General Consulting (since 2009)=== As Smarthomes was wound-down in 2009, Gallagher began to concentrate on business consulting, motivational speaking and journalism, with resultant fees paid through his firm, Beech House Training and Consultants Limited ("BHTC").{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/retail-and-services/se%C3%A1n-gallagher-s-company-beach-house-records-accumulated-loss-1.1622414?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Fretail-and-services%2Fse%25C3%25A1n-gallagher-s-company-beach-house-records-accumulated-loss-1.1622414|title=Seán Gallagher’s company Beach House records accumulated loss|publisher=[[Irish Times]]|date=10 December 2013|quote=Former presidential candidate works a journalist and motivational speaker}} BHTC came under scrutiny during the 2011 Presidential campaign, and in October 2011, Professor of Management at UCD, Niamh Brennan, said that she had a "bad vibe", having read the BHTC accounts.{{efn|name="loan"|The accounts of Gallagher's consulting company, BHTC, listed a Director Loan of €82,829, which was 70% of BHTC's net assets. The [[Revenue Commissioners]] prohibit Director Loans in excess of 10% of net assets because of their use in tax avoidance (e.g. where the Director avoids paying company tax and dividend tax, or salary tax (depending how the Director extractes the profits), by giving themselves a loan, and then never paying it back, and usually winding down the company who writes off the loan.}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/questions-remain-surrounding-gallagher-s-financial-affairs-1.631022|title=Questions remain surrounding Gallagher's financial affairs|publisher=[[Irish Times]]|author=Colm Keena|date=25 October 2011}} The accounts also indicated that Gallagher had funded at least one of his ''Dragons' Den'' investments through BHTC fees,{{efn|name="z2"}} and journalists questioned the level of Gallagher's net worth. In February 2018, Gareth Sheridan, the 28-year-old founder of vitamin patch start-up Nutribrand, appointed Gallagher to its Board.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/business/irish-firm-appoints-gallagher-to-board-828016.html|title=Irish firm appoints Gallagher to board|date=14 February 2018|publisher=[[The Irish Examiner]]|quote=Those filings show it had almost $2.42m (€1.97m) in assets at the end of October, mainly accounting for the value of its patents. In the quarter, its costs and administrative expenses contributed to a net loss of $107,732. For the full nine months, it posted a net loss of $263,311. Mr Sheridan said a small start-up loan to South Dublin County Council had all but been paid back.}} In September 2018, it was reported that Gallagher was one of two Directors of a regional industrial-office leasing company called Clyde Real Estate, and that his consulting company for motivational speaking was, Business Matters Limited.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/politics/how-former-dragons-den-star-sean-gallagher-expanded-his-business-interests-since-failed-ras-bid-37265831.html|title=How former Dragons Den star Seán Gallagher expanded his business interests since failed Áras bid|date=16 September 2018|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|author1=Cormac McQuinn|author2=Kevin Doyle}} ==Political career== ===Fianna Fáil (1981–2011)=== The ''Candidate Profile for Connacht/Ulster'' from the 9th [[Ógra Fianna Fáil]] youth conference in November 1984, lists Seán Gallagher age 22, and states that he joined Fianna Fáil in 1981, and by 1984 was Chair of Cavan Ógra Comhairle Dáilcheantair (constituency council).{{cite web|url=https://irishelectionliterature.com/2014/08/06/candidate-profiles-including-micheal-martin-sean-gallagher-from-the-1984-ogra-fianna-fail-conference-clar/|title=Candidate Profiles (Including Micheál Martin, Seán Gallagher) From The 1984 Ógra Fianna Fáil Conference Clár|date=14 August 2014|publisher=IRISH ELECTION LITERATURE}} Various references are made to Gallagher later becoming the national head of Ógra Fianna Fáil, and in a letter in 2009 to the Fianna Fáil party when seeking election to the Fianna Fáil National Executive, Gallagher said: "I first served on the National Executive with Charlie Haughey from 1985 to 1987 when I was head of Ógra Fianna Fáil nationally".{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/gallagher-spoke-of-30-years-work-for-ff-party-26785262.html|title=Gallagher spoke of 30 years' work for FF party|date=24 October 2011|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|author=Michael Brennan}} After leaving Ogra, Gallagher said: "I later worked full time for the party in Fianna Fáil headquarters, supporting members like yourself in raising much-needed funds for the work of the party." From 1990 to 1993, Gallagher worked as a full-time [[Political consulting|political advisor]] to then Fianna Fáil TD and [[Minister for Health (Ireland)|Minister for Health]]{{efn|name="rory"}} [[Rory O'Hanlon]]. O'Hanlon was part of [[Charles Haughey]]'s cabinet, and lost his cabinet minister position when Albert Reynolds came to power in Fianna Fáil in 1992. In October 2011, Gallagher said of his time with O'Hanlon: "I had a network of contacts built up within departments so good that other ministers would ring me to get things done. I just knew my way around the system". In October 2011, Gallagher stated that he: "... did not have any connection with the party between 1993 [...] and 2007 when he acted as a campaign manager for Louth’s Séamus Kirk".{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/gallagher-has-never-ever-been-secretive-of-fianna-fail-links-188368-Jul2011/|title=Gallagher has “never ever been secretive” of Fianna Fáil links|date=28 July 2011|publisher=[[TheJournal.ie]]|quote=The Dragons’ Den investor said he did not have any connection with the party between 1993 – when he finished working as a political secretary for then-Health minister and Cavan-Monaghan TD Rory O’Hanlon – and 2007 when he acted as a campaign manager for Louth's Séamus Kirk.}} In June 2006, Gallagher, while still CEO of SmartHomes, became Director of Elections for Fianna Fáil Louth TD and parliamentary party Chairman, [[Séamus Kirk]], whose seat was under threat from [[Sinn Féin]]. In the [[Irish general election, 2007|May 2007 general election]], Kirk was successfully re-elected and topped the poll, even beating his fellow Fianna Fáil running mate, the then [[Minister for Justice and Equality|Minister for Justice]], [[Dermot Ahern]].{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/football-injury-steered-him-to-politics-1.756521|title=Football injury steered him into politics|date=14 October 2009|publisher=Irish Independent|author=Harry McGee|quote=His seat was considered to be among those most at risk in the 2007 general election with the entry of Fine Gael MEP Mairead McGuinness into the field. Kirk adopted a far stronger republican tone during the campaign. In the event, he topped the poll ahead of his Fianna Fáil colleague, then minister for justice Dermot Ahern.}} In July 2008, Gallagher hosted a €5,000 per-head fund-raising dinner for 40 people in the Crowne Plaza Hotel in Dundalk, County Louth for the new [[Taoiseach]], [[Brian Cowen]].{{cite web | url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/sean-gallagher-linked-to-secret-ff-fundraiser-26783854.html | title=Seán Gallagher linked to secret FF fundraiser|date=20 October 2011|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|author=Fionnan Sheahan}} The event became a source of controversy in the 2011 presidential election as to whether Gallagher was specifically requesting, and collecting, cheques, or whether they were voluntary.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/regionals/droghedaindependent/news/gallagher-controversy-lingers-on-27160922.html|title=Gallagher controversy lingers on|date=16 September 2011|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]}} In 2009, Gallagher campaigned, and was successfully elected to the National Executive of Fianna Fáil representing the Louth branch. On 5 January 2011, he formally resigned from the National Executive. Gallagher had also resigned from his local Louth Fianna Fáil Ravensdale Cummann in March 2010.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/gallagher-reveals-his-plan-to-bring-dirty-nappies-and-pitterpatter-of-tiny-feet-to-the-aras-26780801.html | title=Gallagher reveals his plan to bring dirty nappies and pitter-patter of tiny feet to the Aras | date=11 October 2011 | publisher=[[Irish Independent]] | quote=He said he was also happy to clarify the timeline and when exactly he did leave Fianna Fáil. "I did attend two meetings of the party's executive in July and December 2009. I stepped down then as a member of the Ravensdale Cumann in Co Louth on March 1, 2010," he said. "I then signaled verbally in September 2010 that I was stepping down as a member of the executive and I formally put that in writing in order to allow the executive to replace me and that happened on January 5, 2011."}} ===2011 presidential campaign=== {{main|Irish presidential election, 2011}} In May 2011, it was reported that Gallagher would likely seek a nomination in the 2011 Irish presidential election.{{cite news|url=http://www.sbpost.ie/news/ireland/gallagher-plans-to-swap-den-for-run-at-the-park-56055.html|title=Gallagher plans to swap Den for run at the Park|last=Connolly|first=Niamh|date=1 May 2011|work=Sunday Business Post|accessdate=23 June 2011}} In June 2011, it was reported Gallagher approached Fianna Fáil [[Oireachtas]] members to run as an Independent candidate, but with a "semi-detached" relationship to the party.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2011/0507/1224296378500.html|title='Dragon' seeks FF support for Park bid|last=McGee|first=Harry|date=7 May 2011|work=The Irish Times|accessdate=23 June 2011}} In June 2011, he received the fourth and final required nomination, of a local council,{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/0912/president.html|title=Two independents receive Áras nominations|date=28 September 2011|publisher=RTÉ News|accessdate=28 September 2011}} and he handed in his nomination papers on 27 September 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2011/0927/breaking22.html|title=Gallagher hands in nomination papers|date=27 September 2011|publisher=The Irish Times|accessdate=27 September 2011|first=Harry|last=Mcgee}} Gallagher was one of seven candidates, and launched his campaign at the [[Royal Hibernian Academy]] in Dublin on 2 October 2011.{{cite news |url= http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/gallagher-officially-launches-aras-campaign-522880.html |title= Gallagher officially launches Áras campaign |date=2 October 2011 |work= [[Irish Examiner]] |accessdate= 2 October 2011}} Throughout his campaign, Gallagher adopted the use of social media as an alternative to posters. He had the highest number of followers of the candidates on [[Facebook]], and the second highest on [[Twitter]].{{cite news|url=http://latersocial.com|title=Irish Presidential Election 2011|date=17 October 2011|work=Later Social|accessdate=17 October 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111010182420/http://latersocial.com/|archivedate=10 October 2011|df=dmy-all}} On 25 September 2011, the first of six major RED C and MRBI opinion polls (see main Wikipedia article) in the campaign, ranked Gallagher 2nd last at 11%. The first of eight television debates took place on 30 September 2011, and appearing on ''[[The Late Late Show (Irish TV series)|The Late Late Show]]'' alongside the other candidates, Gallagher confirmed that he came from "the Fianna Fáil gene pool". The Irish Times described his performance as: "he struggled to give his idea play".{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/presidential-debate-gives-viewers-few-talking-points-1.611312|publisher=[[Irish Times]]|author=Paul Cullen|title=Presidential debate gives viewers few talking points|date=1 October 2011}} On 6 October 2011, the second main opinion poll, from RED C, ranked Gallagher 2nd, behind Higgins, at 20%. As Gallagher rose in the polls in October, scrutiny came on his business dealings, and Fianna Fáil heritage (which were linked via State grants, and State Board appointments). Attention came to the €830,000 in State grants Smarthomes received, which exceeded to the total profits the company made for Gallagher;{{efn|name="z1"|Journalists revealed the Smarthomes accounts showed that the combined Irish State grant loans of €830,000, and the €750,000 of BES investor loans, exceeded the total cumulative profits that Smarthomes made up to 2010, and exceeded the total earnings (salary, rent and royalties) that Gallagher, and his co-founder Derek Roddy, took from the business,}} and that his previous employer, the LCEB, had seed-funded his business with €25,395; and that Gallagher had tried to avoid repaying this seed-funding.{{efn|name="LCEB"}} His appointment to three State Boards, some after being elected to the Fianna Fáil National Executive in 2009, were noted, however, Gallagher responded that he donated some of the State Board fees to charity.{{cite news |url= http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2011/1003/breaking34.html |title= Gallagher, Davis reveal earnings | author1 =Harry McGee | author2 = Marie O'Halloran |date=3 October 2011 |work= [[The Irish Times]] |accessdate= 3 October 2011 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111003201221/https://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2011/1003/breaking34.html | archivedate = 2011-10-03 }} After avoiding criticising Fianna Fáil, Gallagher said: "the party had moved away from the grassroots".{{cite news |url= https://www.irishtimes.com/news/gallagher-distances-himself-from-ff-1.885206 |title= Gallagher distances himself from FF |publisher= [[Irish Times]] |author=Barry Roche | date=13 October 2011 | quote=Asked by Miriam O'Callaghan on the Prime Time debate if he felt Fianna Fáil had let the country down, Mr Gallagher said that he could not answer for Fianna Fáil, but today he moved to counter suggestions that he had been equivocal on the issue. [...] "I was asked to condemn Fianna Fáil, and the first thing that came into my mind was the thousands of ordinary decent men and women who are the grassroots of Fianna Fáil . . . and I didn't want to condemn them because they weren't in government, they weren't in Cabinet.}} His post-Smarthomes dealings revealed inappropriate Director loans of €82,829,{{efn|name="loan"}} which had to be repaid.{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/sean-gallagher-e80000-loan-was-an-accounting-mistake-258502-Oct2011/|title=Seán Gallagher: €80,000 loan was 'an accounting mistake'|author=Michael Freeman|publisher=[[TheJournal.ie]]|date=20 October 2011}} Journalists questioned whether he was a millionaire, and noted some ''Dragons' Den'' investments were paid via fees.{{efn|name="z2"|The Irish times would later report that some of the ''Dragons' Den'' companies did not receive the investment that Gallagher had promised.}} After three further television debates on 4, 11 and 12 October 2011, a 16 October RED C poll, ranked Gallagher 1st with 39% of the poll, with Higgins 2nd with 27%.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/1015/president.html|title=Poll shows Gallagher leading Áras race |date=17 October 2011|work=RTÉ News|accessdate=17 October 2011}} After three television and radio debates on 18, 22 and 24 October, Gallagher would maintain this rank, and increase polling to 40% by the final RED C poll on 22 October 2011, and the final MRBI poll on 23 October 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/gallagher-extends-lead-in-latest-presidential-opinion-polls-260880-Oct2011/|title=Gallagher extends lead in latest Áras opinion polls |date=24 October 2011|work=Journal.ie|accessdate=24 October 2011}} On Monday, 24 October, three days before the election, Gallagher suffered a severe setback in the final debate on [[Pat Kenny]]'s ''[[The Frontline (Irish TV programme)|The Frontline]]'', watched by an audience of 900,000. Martin McGuinness said that he had been contacted by an unnamed man (later verified as fuel-seller, Hugh Morgan), who would confirm that Gallagher had collected a cheque for €5,000 after a 2008 Fianna Fáil fund-raiser, which Gallagher had previously denied.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/how-se%C3%A1n-gallagher-nearly-became-president-of-ireland-in-2011-1.3611550|title=How Seán Gallagher nearly became president of Ireland in 2011|date=29 August 2018|author=Pat Leahy|publisher=[[Irish Times]]}} Later in the show, Kenny, read out a tweet live on air, subsequently proven to be from an anonymous source, that the unnamed man would hold a press conference next day.{{efn|The Irish Independent reported: At 10.39pm, a tweet was posted to a Twitter feed "#aras11". The Twitter account responsible was "@mcguinness4Pres". It read: "The man that Gallagher took the cheque from will be at a press conference tomorrow. #aras11."}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/rte-accused-over-fake-tweet-that-scuppered-gallaghers-aras-bid-26796139.html|title=RTÉ accused over fake tweet that scuppered Gallagher's Aras bid|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|author=Jody Corcoran|date=27 November 2011}} McGuinness resumed his attack, and Gallagher, acknowledging he knew the man, called him a "convicted criminal and fuel smuggler". Gallagher then addressed the audience and, as the [[Irish Times]] would later chronicle: "he also made comments that had very unfortunate overtones for a man denying Fianna Fáil connections – including "no recollection" and "if he gave me an envelope".{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/gallagher-tweet-was-fake-news-before-term-was-invented-1.3333078|publisher=[[Irish Times]]|author=Harry McGee|date=20 December 2017|title=Gallagher tweet was fake news before term was invented|quote=It reopened the matter and allowed McGuinness to stoke up the earlier attack. This time Gallagher referred directly to the man, disparaging him. In so doing he also made comments that had very unfortunate overtones for a man denying Fianna Fáil connections – including “no recollection” and “if he gave me an envelope”. Those phrases recalled excuses of disgraced Fianna Fáil politicians}}{{cite web|url=https://www.broadsheet.ie/2011/10/25/gallagher-and-lies/|title=Seán Gallagher: Biffo’s Bagman|date=25 October 2011|quote=Transcrpit of sections of Seán Gallagher's interaction with Glena Lynch, and Martin McGuinness, on ''The Frontline'' debate, 24 October 2011}} On 25 October, Hugh Morgan made a statement claiming Gallagher collected the cheque from him at Morgan Fuels in Armagh. Gallagher denied this event occurred. Martin McGuinness said that he had "done a service" to the Irish people in bringing the affair to light.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/gallagher-repeats-cheque-denial-1.885959|title=Gallagher repeats cheque denial|date=26 October 2011|publisher=[[Irish Times]]}} Further scrutiny came on the accounts of his consulting business, BHTC, from audience questions the previous night, and his Director's loan of €82,829{{efn|name="loan"}} from BHTC. On 25 October, [[University College Dublin|UCD]] Professor Niamh Brennan described the BHTC accounts to [[The Irish Times]] as having a "bad vibe". On 25 October, on Pat Kenny's radio show, Gallagher questioned the motives of an audience member who asked about the €82,829{{efn|name="loan"}} loan on ''The Frontline'', however, a few minutes later, Glenna Lynch, a then-unknown housewife and mother of three with no political affiliations,{{efn|Glenna Lynch also owned a small interior design business and was familiar with Irish revenue rules, and typical abuses, regarding Director Loans. She would go on to join the [[Social Democrats]] and unsuccessfully contest the [[Irish general election, 2016|general election in 2016]].{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/glenna-lynch-to-run-for-social-democrats-in-general-election-1.2364753|title=Glenna Lynch to run for Social Democrats in general election|date=24 September 2015|publisher=[[Irish Times]]|author=Mary Minihan|}}}} called into the show to reveal herself as that audience member saying: "I think it's extraordinary that Seán believes normal people, voters, don’t have the right to ask a question".{{cite web|url=https://www.broadsheet.ie/2011/10/25/glenda-lynch-and-the-dragon/|title=Glena and the Dragon|quote=Transcrpit of Seán Gallagher interview on the Pat Kenny radio show | date=25 October 2011|publisher=Broadsheet}} On 27 October 2011, Gallagher received 28.5% of first preference votes in the election, leaving him in second place behind Michael D. Higgins. On 30 October, [[The Guardian]], chronicling the reasons for Gallagher's fall in support, reported that a final RTÉ poll showed that 28% of Irish voters changed their mind in the last week of the campaign, with 58% of those switching from Gallagher.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/oct/30/ireland-turned-against-sean-gallagher|title=Why Ireland turned against presidential favourite Seán Gallagher|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|author=Christine Bohan|date=30 October 2011}} On 7 March 2012, the Irish [[Broadcasting Authority of Ireland]] upheld Gallagher's complaint about unfair treatment regarding how RTÉ handled the unverified tweet on the final Pat Kenny debate.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/bai-upholds-sean-gallagher-complaint-over-frontline-tweet-26829567.html|title=BAI upholds Seán Gallagher complaint about Frontline tweet|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|date=27 March 2012}} On 19 December 2017, it was reported that RTÉ agreed to pay Gallagher a sum of €130,000 as part of a confidential legal settlement arising from the final Pat Kenny debate.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/courts/revealed-the-sixfigure-sum-paid-to-gallagher-by-rte-over-tweetgate-error-36423593.html|title=Revealed: The six-figure sum paid to Gallagher by RTÉ over Tweetgate error|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|date=20 December 2017|author=Shane Phelan}} === 2018 presidential campaign === {{main|Irish presidential election, 2018}} In August 2018, Gallagher announced that he would seek a nomination to run for [[President of Ireland|president]] again and contest the [[Irish presidential election, 2018|2018 presidential election]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/se%C3%A1n-gallagher-says-he-will-seek-nomination-for-presidential-election-1.3611208|title=Seán Gallagher says he will seek nomination for presidential election|work=The Irish Times|access-date=10 September 2018}} On 10 September 2018, with the support of four [[Local government in the Republic of Ireland|county councils]], Gallagher became the second candidate in the 2018 election to secure a nomination, after the incumbent Michael D. Higgins (who has the right to nominate himself).{{Cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/politics/2018/0910/992732-presidential-election-councils/|title=Freeman and Gallagher both secure nominations for Áras bids|date=10 September 2018|work=RTÉ News|access-date=10 September 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/michael-d-higgins-confirms-he-will-seek-a-second-term-as-president-37099893.html|title=Michael D Higgins confirms he will seek a second term as president|work=Irish Independent|access-date=10 September 2018}} ==Personal life== Gallagher married Irene McCausland in 1997, while he was working with the Louth Country Enterprise Board, and they divorced and annulled in 1999. In 2010, he married Patricia "Trish" O'Connor, a cosmetic company representative, from Kanturk, Co Cork. They used to live in [[Blackrock, County Louth]],{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/lifestyle/gallagher-the-lessons-i-learnt-from-my-first-wife-2907004.html|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|author=Gemma O'Doherty|title=Gallagher: the lessons I learnt from my first wife|date=15 October 2011}} but now live in [[Delgany]], [[County Wicklow]], and have two children.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/regionals/braypeople/news/gallagher-to-decide-on-presidency-this-week-37238481.html|title=Gallagher to decide on Presidency this week|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|date=25 August 2018}} Gallagher's profile in the Board report of the InterTradeIreland 2007 accounts, noted that Gallagher was a 1st [[Dan (rank)|dan]] black-belt in both Judo and Karate. ==Bibliography== *{{cite book | last1 = Gallagher | first1 = Sean | title = Secrets to Success: Inspiring Stories from Leading Entrepreneurs | publisher = Mercier Press Limited | isbn = 978-1781175255 | year = 2018 }} ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{Official website|seangallagher2018.com}} {{Charity Lords of the Ring}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gallagher, Sean}} [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Fianna Fáil politicians]] [[Category:Reality show winners]] [[Category:Candidates for President of Ireland]] [[Category:Irish television personalities]] [[Category:Participants in Irish reality television series]] [[Category:People educated at St Patrick's College, Cavan]] [[Category:Alumni of St Patrick's College, Maynooth]] [[Category:Alumni of Ulster University]] [[Category:People from County Cavan]] [[Category:Irish businesspeople]]

revision.text:
{{For|the Jully Black song|Sweat of Your Brow}} [[File:'The feast of reason, and the flow of soul,' - ie - the wits of the age, setting the table in a roar by James Gillray.jpg|thumb|right|300px|As [[James Gillray]], the artist of this 1797 etching, died in 1815, his works are in the [[public domain]] throughout the world. However, under the "sweat of the brow" doctrine, new copyright claims could be made over mechanical reproductions of the etching, due to the skill and labor involved in the reproduction.]]
'''Sweat of the brow''' is an [[intellectual property]] [[Legal doctrine|law doctrine]], chiefly related to [[copyright]] law. According to this doctrine, an [[author]] gains rights through simple diligence during the creation of a work, such as a database, or a directory. Substantial creativity or "originality" is not required.
Under a "sweat of the brow" doctrine, the creator of a copyrighted work, even if it is completely unoriginal, is entitled to have his effort and expense protected, and no one else may use such a work without permission, but must instead recreate the work by independent research or effort. The classic example is a [[telephone directory]]. In a "sweat of the brow" jurisdiction, such a directory may not be copied, but instead a competitor must independently collect the information to issue a competing directory. The same rule generally applies to databases and lists of facts.
[[Civil law (legal system)|Civil law]] jurisdictions have traditionally used the similar but not identical concept of ''[[droit d'auteur]]''. [[European Union law]] tends to harmonize the protection of intellectual property throughout member states and the doctrine thus gains more influence. In the Databases Directive 96/9/EC{{emdash}}the [[Member State of the European Union|member states of the EU]] are obliged to confer protection known as the [[database right]] on non-original databases, that is on those that embody no creativity, but are a consequence of substantial investment (financial, labour etc.).<ref>[http://www.bonnanwalt.de/rg/internet/law/eu/RiLi96-9-eg.html EU Richtlinie 96/9/EG] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070621055429/http://www.bonnanwalt.de/rg/internet/law/eu/RiLi96-9-eg.html |date=2007-06-21 }} {{de icon}}</ref>
==Etymology== In a traditional [[English language|English]] [[idiom]], the ''sweat of one's brow'' refers to the effort expended in labor, and the value created thereby.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://machaut.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/WEBSTER.page.sh?page=1457|page=1457|accessdate=2007-05-30|work=Webster's Revised Unabridged Dictionary (1913 ed)|title=Sweat, v. t.|publisher=ARTFL Project|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060303004057/http://machaut.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/WEBSTER.page.sh?page=1457|archivedate=2006-03-03|df=}}</ref> The phrase is famously used in English translations of {{sourcetext|source=Bible|version=King James|book=Genesis|chapter=3|verse=19}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newlivingtranslation.com/05discoverthenlt/ssresults.asp?txtSearchString=Genesis+3|accessdate=2007-05-30|title=New Living Translation|publisher=Tyndale House Publishers, inc.|quote=By the sweat of your brow will you have food to eat}}</ref> The law doctrine takes its name from this idiom.
==By country==
===United States=== {{see also|Copyright law in the United States}} The [[United States]] rejected this doctrine in the 1991 [[United States Supreme Court]] case ''[[Feist Publications v. Rural Telephone Service]]'';<ref>{{ussc|499|340|1991}}</ref> until then it had been upheld in a number of US copyright cases.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}}
Under the ''Feist'' ruling in the US, mere collections of facts are considered unoriginal and thus not protected by copyright, no matter how much work went into [[collation|collating]] them. The arrangement and presentation of a collection may be original, but not if it is "simple and obvious" such as a list in [[alphabetical]] or [[chronological]] order.
===United Kingdom=== Under the [[Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988]], for copyright to subsist in a work, that work must be original. However, courts have not adopted a literal reading of this requirement. For over a hundred years, English courts have held that a significant expenditure of labour is sufficient. The consequence of this is that if A makes a work, in which copyright subsists, and B subsequently adds his skill, judgement and labour, altering the form of A's work, B will potentially have a copyright in the work he produces. This suggests that copyright is not about protecting ideas, because one can acquire a copyright by expending skill, labour, and judgement, but no creativity or inventiveness.
However, in March 2012, a case was taken to the [[European Court of Justice]], in which [[Football DataCo]] claimed [[copyright infringement]] over web sites which were reproducing match schedules from several major [[association football|football]] leagues. Football DataCo asserted that these schedules were copyrighted works due to the skill and labour involved in their preparation, and that the company was given exclusive rights to license their reproduction. Based on its interpretation of British law, the court rejected the notion that labour and skill was enough to grant protection to a work, since "unless the procedures for creating the lists concerned as described by the national court are supplemented by elements reflecting originality in the selection or arrangement of the data contained in those lists, they do not suffice for those lists to be protected by the copyright laid down in the directive."<ref name=bbcn-dataco>{{cite web|last=Wilson|first=Bill|title=Football match fixture list copyright claim rejected|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-17218968|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=6 March 2012}}</ref>
In a copyright notice on 'digital images, photographs and the internet' last updated in November 2015, the UK [[Intellectual Property Office (United Kingdom)|Intellectual Property Office]] confirmed that digital reproductions of [[public domain]] images are not protected by copyright, arguing that "according to the Court of Justice of the European Union which has effect in UK law, copyright can only subsist in subject matter that is original in the sense that it is the author’s own ‘intellectual creation’. Given this criterion, it seems unlikely that what is merely a retouched, digitised image of an older work can be considered as ‘original’."<ref name=IPO-cnote>{{cite web|author=UK Intellectual Property Office|title=Copyright Notice: digital images, photographs and the internet|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/481194/c-notice-201401.pdf|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref>
====Examples==== In ''[[Walter v Lane]]'' (1900) (Pre-CDPA), reporters took shorthand notes of a speech, punctuated them, etc. and published them in the [[The Times|''Times'']] newspaper. The court held that the reporters were authors of the published speech, and, as such, owned a copyright in the published speeches, because of the considerable skill, labour, and judgement they exercised.
In ''[[University of London Press Ltd v University Tutorial Press Ltd]]'',<ref>University of London Press v University Tutorial [1916] 2 Ch 601</ref> the question arose as to whether certain mathematics exam papers were original literary works. The exam papers just consisted of conventional maths problems in a conventional manner. The court held that originality does not mean that the work must be an expression of individual thought. The simple fact that the authors drew on a body of knowledge common to mathematicians did not compromise originality. The requirement of originality, it was held, does not require that expression be in an original or novel form. It does, however, require that the work not be copied from another work. It must originate from the author. As such, even though these were the same old maths problems every student is familiar with, and even though there was no creative input, the skill, labour, and judgement of the authors was sufficient to make the papers original literary works.
In ''[[Cummins v Bond]]'', a psychic in a trance claimed to have written down what spirits told her, through a process of [[automatic writing]]. In court, she accepted that she was not the creative author of the writing. The creative input, had, presumably, come from the spirits.<ref>{{cite web|author=William Patry |url=http://williampatry.blogspot.gr/2005/08/authorship-and-religion.html |title=The Patry Copyright Blog: Authorship and Religion |publisher=Williampatry.blogspot.gr |date=2005-08-10 |accessdate=2013-10-02}}</ref> Nonetheless, the court held that she had exercised sufficient labour and skill in translating and transcribing what the spirits told her, so she had a copyright in the resulting literary work.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
===Germany=== In certain cases, German law grants ancillary copyrights (''Leistungsschutzrecht'') due to the effort involved in the production or exploitation of creative works.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nolte|first1=Georg|title=Zur Forderung der Presseverleger nach Einführung eines speziellen Leistungsschutzrechts: Eine kritische Auseinandersetzung|journal=Zeitschrift für Geistiges Eigentum|date=1 July 2010|volume=2|issue=2|pages=165–195|doi=10.1628/186723710792175149|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/mohr/zge/2010/00000002/00000002/art00002|language=de}}</ref> In 2016, a [[Landgericht Berlin|regional court in Berlin]] ruled that digitized versions of public domain paintings were entitled to new copyrights due to the effort and expertise necessary to create the reproductions. The case is being appealed.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Moody|first1=Glyn|title=Digitising public domain images creates a new copyright, rules German court [Updated]|url=http://arstechnica.co.uk/tech-policy/2016/06/digitising-public-domain-images-creates-a-new-copyright-germany/|website=Ars Technica UK|accessdate=5 July 2016|date=23 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite court|litigants=Reiss-Engelhorn Museum (REM) of the City of Mannheim v. Wikimedia Foundation|url=https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/foundation/5/52/Reiss-Engelhorn_Museum_%28REM%29_of_the_City_of_Mannheim_v._Wikimedia_Foundation_Landgericht.pdf|court=Landgericht Berlin|date=2016|accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref>
===Israel=== Israeli law requires that a work exhibit some [[threshold of originality|degree of originality]] in order to be copyrightable. In other words, Israeli law does not subscribe to the "sweat of the brow" doctrine.<ref>Tempska, Urzula (2002). [http://scholarship.law.marquette.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1036&context=iplr "'Originality' After the Dead Sea Scrolls Decision: Implications for the American Law of Copyright"]. ''Marquette Intellectual Property Law Review'' '''6''' (1): 132.</ref> However, the amount of originality required is minimal, and the transliteration or interpretation of an artifact is covered by copyright.<ref>Elkin-Koren, Niva (2001). [http://www.houstonlawreview.org/archive/downloads/38-2_pdf/HLR38P445.pdf "Of Scientific Claims and Proprietary Rights: Lessons from the Dead Sea Scrolls"], ''Houston Law Review'' '''38''' (2): 458, 460.</ref>
===Uruguay=== Uruguayan law requires that the work should have some degree of originality to be protected by copyright. Uruguayan law, therefore, does not subscribe to the sweat of the brow doctrine.{{Citation needed|date=August 2013}}
==See also== *[[Liberalism#Classical_and_modern|Lockean Classical liberalism]] *[[Labour theory of value]] *[[Sui generis database right]] *[[Sweat equity]] *[[Threshold of originality]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Intellectual property law]] [[Category:Copyright law]]

revision.text:
{{coord|40.7093|-74.0140|region:US-NY_type:landmark|format=dms|display=title}} [[File:Washington Street Plaza - 2.JPG|thumb|Washington Street Plaza]] [[File:Washington Street Plaza - 1.JPG|thumb|Washington Street Plaza at Albany and Washington Streets]] The '''Washington Street Plaza''' is a [[Pedestrian zone|pedestrian plaza]] along [[Washington Street (Manhattan)|Washington Street]] between Carlisle and [[Albany Street (Manhattan)|Albany Street]]<nowiki/>s on the west side of the [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]] in [[Lower Manhattan]]. It opened on May 23, 2013.<ref name="de">{{cite news|work=Downtown Express|title=Washington Street to gain public plaza|url=http://www.downtownexpress.com/2012/11/14/washington-street-to-gain-public-plaza/||author=Aline Reynolds | date=November 14, 2012 | accessdate=June 17, 2014}}</ref>
With an [[epoxy]] gravel placed over the street, it contains granite blocks, red chairs, tables, and potted plants.<ref name="de"/>
Its construction was delayed for several years and debated within [[Manhattan Community Board 1]], although it was ultimately approved by the executive committee. The [[Alliance for Downtown New York]], the [[Business Improvement District]] led by [[Elizabeth H. Berger]], argued that the plaza would, according to the [[Downtown Express]], "improve pedestrian mobility" around the [[National September 11 Memorial & Museum|September 11 Memorial]] and allow the Alliance to install a tourist kiosk. Referring to the Alliance's report "Five Principles for Greenwich South," which advocated for the plaza, she said: “One of the things that we looked at was how to capitalize on the old-world geometry of the street plan to create a sense of destination and gathering places.... There’ll be an attractive space not only for visitors but for people who live and work in the area to congregate.” Some residents believed, however, that "it would disrupt traffic and complicate an already crowded area."<ref name="de"/>
The administration of former Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]], through Jeffrey Mandel, an adviser to Deputy Mayor [[Robert K. Steel]], also advanced that the plaza would benefit residents of the Downtown neighborhood while helping to mitigate foot traffic from tourists. He said, "[the plaza] pushes a couple of big dominos forward by creating a place that's not just attractive and desirable for the folks down here but that has beneficial impacts in the way of mitigation."<ref name="de"/>
The plaza's construction was delayed by [[Hurricane Sandy]]. Representing the exiting Bloomberg administration, Mandel said, "We think it's important to make our best efforts in our last hours in the neighborhood."<ref>{{cite news|work=Tribeca Trib|title=City to Turn Drab Stretch of Washington into Pedestrian Plaza|url=http://tribecatrib.com/content/city-turn-drab-stretch-washington-pedestrian-plaza||author=Jessica Terrell | accessdate=June 17, 2014}}</ref>
Activists for the recognition of the history of the [[Lower West Side, Manhattan|Lower West Side]] and the [[Little Syria]] neighborhood have argued that the plaza would be an ideal place for historical signage. In anticipation of its construction, they pursued a resolution in support of signage from Community Board 1.<ref>{{cite news|work=[[Huffington Post]]|title=Washington Street Plaza in 'Little Syria' Should Be Opportunity for New York|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/todd-fine/nyc-little-syria_b_3283834.html||author=Todd Fine | date=May 20, 2013 | accessdate=June 17, 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Parks in Manhattan]] [[Category:Financial District, Manhattan]]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Malay name|Zulhasnan|Rafique}} {{Infobox politician | honorific-prefix = [[Malay titles#Honorary styles|Yang Berbahagia]] [[Squadron leader|Major]] [[Mandatory retirement|(Rtd.)]] [[Malay titles#Tan Sri|Tan Sri]] [[Malay titles#Datuk Sri|Datuk Seri Utama]] [[Doctor of Philosophy|Dr.]] [[Hajji|Haji]] | honorific-suffix = {{small|[[Order of Loyalty to the Crown of Malaysia#Commander|PSM]] [[Order of the Defender of the Realm#Member|AMN]] [[Orders, decorations, and medals of the Malaysian states and federal territories#Federal Territories|SUMW]] [[Orders, decorations, and medals of Pahang|SSAP]] [[List of post-nominal letters (Penang)|DGPN]] [[Orders, decorations, and medals of Pahang|DIMP]]}} | name = Zulhasnan Rafique | native_name = ذولهسنن بن رفيقاواي | image = | caption = |office1 = 15th [[Malaysian Ambassador to the United States]] |monarch1 = [[Muhammad V of Kelantan|Muhammad V]] |primeminister1 = [[Najib Razak]] |term_start1 = 28 December 2016 |term_end1 = 23 April 2018 |predecessor1 = [[Awang Adek Hussin]] |successor1 = | office = [[Minister of Territories (Malaysia)|Minister of Federal Territories]] | primeminister = [[Abdullah Ahmad Badawi]] | monarch = [[Sirajuddin of Perlis|Sirajuddin]]
[[Mizan Zainal Abidin of Terengganu|Mizan Zainal Abidin]] | term_start = 14 February 2006 | term_end = 9 April 2009 | constituency = [[Setiawangsa (federal constituency)|Setiawangsa]] | deputy = [[Saravanan Murugan]] | predecessor = [[Mohd Isa Abdul Samad]]
[[Shahrizat Abdul Jalil]] {{small|''(Acting)''}} | successor = [[Raja Nong Chik Zainal Abidin]] | office2 = [[Ministry of Territories (Malaysia)|Deputy Minister of Federal Territories]] | primeminister2 = Abdullah Ahmad Badawi | monarch2 = Sirajuddin | term_end2 = 14 February 2006 | term_start2 = 27 March 2004 | constituency2 = Setiawangsa | minister2 = Mohd Isa Abdul Samad
Shahrizat Abdul Jalil {{small|''(Acting)''}} | predecessor2 = ''Office established'' | successor2 = [[Abu Seman Yusop]] | parliament3 = Malaysian | constituency_MP3 = [[Setiawangsa (federal constituency)|Setiawangsa]] | term_start3 = 21 March 2004 | term_end3 = 5 May 2013 | majority3 = 19,669 ([[Malaysian general election, 2004|2004]])
8,134 ([[Malaysian general election, 2008|2008]]) | predecessor3 = ''Constituency established'' | successor3 = Ahmad Fauzi Zahari ([[United Malays National Organisation|UMNO]]-[[Barisan Nasional|BN]]) | parliament4 = Malaysian | constituency_MP4 = [[Wangsa Maju (federal constituency)|Wangsa Maju]] | term_start4 = 29 November 1999 | term_end4 = 21 March 2004 | majority4 = 5,618 ([[Malaysian general election, 1999|1999]]) | predecessor4 = Kamal Mat Salih ([[United Malays National Organisation|UMNO]]-[[Barisan Nasional|BN]]) | successor4 = Yew Teong Lock ([[Malaysian Chinese Association|MCA]]-[[Barisan Nasional|BN]]) | birth_name = Zulhasnan bin Rafique | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1954|9|20|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Selangor]], [[Federation of Malaya]] (now [[Malaysia]]) | residence = | death_date = | death_place = | party = [[United Malays National Organisation]] (UMNO) | otherparty = [[Barisan Nasional]] (BN) | occupation = [[Politician]] | profession = Military officer (fighter pilot) | relations = | spouse = Siti Nooriah Razak | children = 3 children | website = www.umnosetiawangsa.com.my | nickname = | allegiance = {{flagicon image|Flag of the Supreme Head of Malaysia.svg}} [[Yang di-Pertuan Agong]] | branch = {{flagicon image|Air Force Ensign of Malaysia.svg}} [[Royal Malaysian Air Force]] | serviceyears = 12 years | rank = [[Squadron leader|Major]] | unit = 12th Squadron RMAF | commands = | battles = Ops Helang Malindo
Ops Kubay
Daoyai Musnah | mawards = | military_blank1 = | military_data1 = | module = | footnotes = }} [[Squadron leader|Major]] [[Mandatory retirement|(Rtd.)]] [[Malay titles#Tan Sri|Tan Sri]] [[Malay titles#Datuk Sri|Datuk Seri Utama]] [[Doctor of Philosophy|Dr.]] [[Hajji|Haji]] '''Zulhasnan bin Rafique''' ([[Jawi alphabet|Jawi]]: ذولهسنن بن رفيقاواي; born 20 September 1954) is a [[Malaysian people|Malaysian]] [[politician]] and the former [[Ministry of Territories (Malaysia)|Minister of Federal Territories]]. He is a former [[Member of Parliament]] of [[Parliament of Malaysia|Malaysia]] for [[Wangsa Maju (federal constituency)|Wangsa Maju]] and [[Setiawangsa (federal constituency)|Setiawangsa]] constituencies{{Cite web| url = http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2006/2/15/nation/13397398&sec=nation | title = Ex-pilot scales new heights as Federal Territories minister | accessdate = 30 January 2010 | date = 15 February 2006 | publisher = ''TheStar Online''}} in [[Kuala Lumpur]] and a supreme council member in the [[United Malay National Organisation]] (UMNO), the largest component party in the previously ruling coalition [[Barisan Nasional]] (BN). ==Life== Zulhasnan joined the [[Royal Malaysian Air Force]] as a fighter pilot and retired in 1985 with the rank of Major (Squadron leader in other countries) before entering politics. ==Politics== Zulhasnan debuted in the [[Malaysian general election, 1999|1999 Malaysian general election]] and won the Wangsa Maju seat to be elected as a Member of Parliament. In the [[Malaysian general election, 2004|2004 general election]], he contested and won the Setiawangsa parliamentary seat. On 27 March 2004, following a cabinet reshuffle by [[Prime Minister of Malaysia|Prime Minister]] [[Abdullah Ahmad Badawi]], the Federal Territory and [[Klang Valley]] Planning and Development Division was upgraded to a full-fledged ministry. Its responsibility expanded to include jurisdiction over the territories of [[Labuan]] and [[Putrajaya]]. Zulhasnan was the first deputy minister to be appointed to the ministry. [[Mohd Isa Abdul Samad]] was the first minister to be appointed. However, Isa was dismissed from office after he was found guilty of corruption charges related to money politics during the [[UMNO]] General Assembly Election of 2005. [[Shahrizat Abdul Jalil]] (then the [[Minister of Women, Family and Community Development (Malaysia)|Minister for Women, Family and Community Development]]) assumed the responsibilities of acting minister until a replacement could be found. On 16 February 2006, Zulhasnan was appointed the Federal Territories Minister. Under the leadership of Zulhasnan, a strategic plan that focused on development plans for all three Federal Territories was created. In the [[Malaysian general election, 2008|2008 election]], he was reelected again as a Member of Parliament. He was dropped from the new cabinet on 9 April 2009 by [[Najib Abdul Razak]] who took over as the 6th Prime Minister. He was not chosen by Barisan Nasional to recontest the Setiawangsa seat in the [[Malaysian general election, 2013|2013 election]].{{cite news|url=http://www.themalaysiantimes.com.my/setiawangsa-zulhasnan-not-one-to-rest-on-his-laurel/|title=Setiawangsa : Zulhasnan not one to rest on his laurels|last=Lingham|first=Mitra|date=3 April 2013|work=The Malaysian Times|accessdate=18 October 2014}} He was appointed as the [[Malaysian Ambassador to the United States]], replacing [[Awang Adek Hussin]] in December 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.malaysiandigest.com/frontpage/29-4-tile/650202-former-ft-minister-zulhasnan-appointed-as-the-new-malaysian-ambassador-to-united-states.html|title=Former FT Minister Zulhasnan Appointed As The New Malaysian Ambassador To United States|work=Malaysian Digest}} But he resigned in April 2018 to contest in the [[Malaysian general election, 2018|2018 election]] the Setiawangsa constituency again.{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2018/04/28/barisans-zulhasnan-making-a-comeback-in-setiawangsa/|title=Barisan’s Zulhasnan making a comeback in Setiawangsa|author= Intan Farhana Zainul|first=|last=|date=28 April 2018|work=[[The Star (Malaysia)]]|accessdate=10 May 2018}} Following the huge swing of votes to the now-governing coalition [[Pakatan Harapan]], he lost and failed to win back his former parliamentary seat.{{cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/bns-big-names-toppled-one-after-another|title=Malaysia Votes 2018: BN's big names toppled, one after another|first=Nadirah|last=H. Rodzi|date=10 May 2018|work=[[The Straits Times]]|accessdate=10 May 2018}} ==Election results== {| class="wikitable" style="margin:0.5em ; font-size:95%" |+ '''[[Dewan Rakyat|Parliament of Malaysia]]'''{{cite web|url=http://semak.spr.gov.my/spr/laporan/5_KedudukanAkhir.php|title=Keputusan Pilihan Raya Umum Parlimen/Dewan Undangan Negeri|publisher=[[Election Commission of Malaysia]]|accessdate=10 May 2013}} Percentage figures based on total turnout, excluding informal votes.{{Cite web | title = Malaysia General Election | work = undiinfo Malaysian Election Data | publisher = [[Malaysiakini]] | url = http://undi.info/# | accessdate = 4 February 2017}} Results only available from the [[Malaysian general election, 2004|2004 election]].{{cite web|url=http://resultpru13.spr.gov.my/module/keputusan/paparan/paparan_laporan.php|title=KEPUTUSAN PILIHAN RAYA UMUM 13|work=Sistem Pengurusan Maklumat Pilihan Raya Umum|publisher=[[Election Commission of Malaysia]] |language=Malay|accessdate=24 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://keputusan.spr.gov.my/|title=SEMAKAN KEPUTUSAN PILIHAN RAYA UMUM KE - 14|publisher=[[Election Commission of Malaysia]] |language=Malay|accessdate=17 May 2018}} Percentage figures based on total turnout.{{cite web|url=https://election.thestar.com.my/|title=The Star Online GE14|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]|accessdate=24 May 2018}} Percentage figures based on total turnout. !|Year !|Constituency !colspan=2| !|Votes !|Pct !colspan=2|Opponent(s) !|Votes !|Pct !|Ballots cast !|Majority !|Turnout |- |[[Malaysian general election, 1999|1999]] |P105 [[Wangsa Maju (federal constituency)|Wangsa Maju]], [[Wilayah Persekutuan|K.L.]] |{{Party shading/Barisan Nasional}} | |{{nowrap|}}'''Zulhasnan Rafique''' ([[United Malays National Organisation|'''UMNO''']]) |align="right" |'''29,997''' |'''55.17%''' |{{Party shading/Keadilan}} | |Marina Mohd. {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}} {{no footnotes|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Zurab Gegenava | image = File:Zurab Gegenava.jpg | caption = Zurab Gegenava at the Festival of [[Festival "Golden Eye"|Golden Eye]] in Georgia, 2010 | native_name = ზურაბ გეგენავა | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1973|01|23}} | birth_place = [[Tbilisi]], Georgia | nationality = [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] | alma_mater = [[Georgian Technical University]] | organization = Innovator | known_for = Festival "Golden Eye" | home_town = Tbilisi | website = {{URL|innovator.ge}} }} '''Zurab Gegenava ''' (Georgian: ზურაბ გეგენავა) – (Born January 23, 1973 , Tbilisi) – is a [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] businessman and a public figure. He is a general director of the company Innovator, the founder of the International Festival of Movie and TV Cameramen "Golden Eye" and the founder of the International Foundation for Innovative Technologies (IFIT). He has a wife and two children.
==Biography ==
Zurab Gegenava was born on January 23, 1973 in [[Tbilisi]]. In 1995 he graduated from [[Georgian Technical University]], the faculty of Economics and Management.
1993 – 1995 – the coordinator of the program "Remembrance" at the International Foundation of Georgian Youth;
1994–1996 – the vice-president of the international TV festival "Mana"; from 1995 to 1996, he worked as an assistant of vice-premier at Municipality of Tbilisi.
1996–1997 – the assistant of the Deputy of State Minister at Georgian State Chancellery;
2000– 2003 – the head of Secretariat for chairman of Georgian TV-Radio Broadcasting;
2003–2004 – head of the Administration at Georgian TV-Radio Broadcasting;
2004– 2005 – head of technical department at [[Georgian Public Broadcaster]];
2005–2006 – the director of service center at [[Georgian Public Broadcaster]].
In 2006, he founded company "Innovator" (former "Indent"), which is working in broadcasting field and its main directions are distribution of modern broadcasting equipment, system integration, warranty and post warranty services.
In 2010 he founded International Foundation for Innovative Technologies (IFIT). The main mission of the foundation is to support the implementation of modern innovative trends in Georgia and the Caucasus Region.
In 2009, he founded the International Festival of Movie and TV Cameramen "Golden Eye". The main goal of the festival is to motivate cameramen and people working in the TV and movie industry and to support their further professional growth.
In 2014, he founded International Exhibition of Broadcast Equipment, which took place in the frames of the festival "Golden Eye". It is noteworthy that this is the first time for Georgia to host such exhibition.
==Professional career==
Zurab Gegenava founded the company Innovator (former Indent) in 2005. The company works in the broadcasting field, its main directions are distribution of modern broadcasting equipment, system integration, warranty and post warranty services.
In 2010, he founded the International Foundation for Innovative Technologies (IFIT). The main mission of the foundation is to support the implementation of modern innovative trends in Georgia and the Caucasus Region.
In 2009, he founded the International Festival of Movie and TV Cameramen "Golden Eye". The main goal of the festival is to motivate the cameramen and people working in TV and movie industry and to support their further professional growth. In 2014 for the first time, "Golden Eye" festival also hosted the 1st International Exhibition of Broadcast Equipment.
